DEBATE.TITLE: SENATOR THE HONOURABLE D. L. CHIPP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling for petitions, I take this opportunity of welcoming Senator Donald Chipp back to the chamber and of saying how pleased we are to see that he has made such a good recovery. We wish him all the best of good health in the future.

—by leave-I thank you, Mr President, and the many honourable senators from all parties who sent spontaneous messages of good will to me during my illness. The genuine warmth and even at times the deep shades of sentimental affection which they expressed sometimes contradicted their public utterances about me. I can assure honourable senators that they were deeply appreciated by my wife and me and I have no doubt that they hastened my recovery. I thank those honourable senators for their messages of good will.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 122 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the introduction of tuition fees for post-graduate and second degree students will:

(i) severely limit access to such levels of study. The ability of a student to pay tuition fees will be the main criterion of entry to such courses. The restricted availability of Commonwealth post-graduate scholarships and the difficulty of finding part-time work in employment related areas further restricts the ability of post-graduate students to pay tuition fees.

(ii) result in higher attrition rates in post-graduate and second degree studies. Recent surveys have indicated that up to 50% of students would be unable to continue their studies if tuition fees at the level of $1,000 per year were introduced. Inability to continue study is both a personal tragedy and a waste of the community's resources.

(iii) limit Australia's capacity to cope with technological, economic and social change. Many degree students who will have to pay tuition fees undertake further study to upgrade their qualifications to cope with changes in their area of employment. Many are forced to undertake retraining in areas outside their current employment because of declining job opportunities in such areas due to economic change. Further study for many students will bring no financial benefit but simply allow them to extend their contribution in the course of their work. For example, thousands of teachers have undertaken further study to gain expertise in such areas as migrant education, remedial literacy and numeracy teaching, curriculum development and so on.

(iv) further restrict access to such study for women students. As a result of the abolition of tuition fees the proportion of women students in tertiary education has increased significantly. Mature age women students have benefited by the opportunity denied them when they left school.

(v) seriously undermine Australia's research effort. Approximately 22% of Australian research takes place in tertiary institutions. The bulk of Australia's basic research is undertaken in universities. The introduction of tuition fees threatens Australia's capacity to cope with major structural change in the economy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject the introduction of tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Recent surveys have indicated that up to 50% of students would be unable to continue their studies if tuition fees at the level of $1,000 per year were introduced. Inability to continue study is both a personal tragedy and a waste of the community's resources.

(iii) limit Australia's capacity to cope with technological, economic and social change. Many degree students who will have to pay tuition fees undertake further study to upgrade their qualifications to cope with changes in their area of employment. Many are forced to undertake retraining in areas outside their current employment because of declining job opportunities in such areas due to economic change. Further study for many students will bring no financial benefit but simply allow them to extend their contribution in the course of their work. For example, thousands of teachers have undertaken further study to gain expertise in such areas as migrant education, remedial literacy and numeracy teaching, curriculum development and so on.

(iv) further restrict access to such study for women students. As a result of the abolition of tuition fees the proportion of women students in tertiary education has increased significantly. Mature age women students have benefited by the opportunity denied them when they left school.

(v) seriously undermine Australia's research effort. Approximately 22% of Australian research takes place in tertiary institutions. The bulk of Australia's basic research is undertaken in universities. The introduction of tuition fees threatens Australia's capacity to cope with major structural change in the economy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject the introduction of tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. A Federal Inquiry has been recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the Gallery of a delegation from the United Kingdom branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, led by the Right Honourable Denis Howell, MP. On behalf of all honourable senators I extend to the delegation a very warm welcome and best wishes for a successful and enjoyable visit to this country.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask the Minister whether he can indicate a date upon which the Government will make and announce the Government's decision in response to the Industries Assistance Commission report on the motor vehicle industry. Quite apart from concern in the motor vehicle industry, I ask the Minister whether he is aware of the detrimental effect of the Government's indecision on industry generally in those towns and cities which are largely dependent on the motor vehicle industry for their economies.

—The Government is very conscious of the necessity to reach, first of all, a correct decision on a very complex matter and, consistent with arriving at a correct decision, an early decision; and it will proceed to do so. I do not think that the Government could put a fixed date on this but it is certainly working towards that end. The Government over the years has done much to promote the growth of manufacturing industry and, indeed, of the automotive industry in Australia. It is fully aware of the impact of the industry on employment and on the welfare of the people of Australia. It will have that in mind during its deliberations and in reaching its conclusions.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to an article appearing in today's Courier-Mail wherein it is stated that the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, is considering a different system of tenure from that which he originally proposed for title of the Aboriginal people of that State in relation to ownership of the reserves and communities in which they now reside. Is the Minister aware of this article? Can he confirm that the Premier is considering such a proposal as outlined in this article?

—I am aware of the article to which Senator Bonner refers. It was abbreviated in the 'Stop Press' column of the Canberra Times this morning. Some people may have seen it. We have had the article sent down from Brisbane. It, indeed, says that the Premier of Queensland has indicated that he has in mind a proposal which goes beyond the previous announcement of 50-year leases for Aboriginal reserves as a form of land tenure. I have not as yet had a chance to learn what those new proposals are. I am unable to advise the honourable senator as to the details of the Premier's proposition. I believe that the statement this morning bears out my belief that an appropriate course to take is to seek to continue negotiation and to seek to work towards an agreed solution to what is a very difficult problem.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to a question that I asked on 24 September concerning the death of the Australian Broadcasting Commission journalist Tony Joyce in Zambia. I now ask: Did the Minister for Foreign Affairs or the Prime Minister raise the question with President Kaunda at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting? Will the Minister table the letter which President Kaunda sent to the Prime Minister last May and which is apparently the official Zambian Government report to the Australian Government on the incident?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister did not, in fact, raise the matter of Tony Joyce during CHOGM. Over the months there had been many exchanges between both governments on this matter. The Prime Minister in his reply to Mr Lionel Bowen in another place on 17 September made very clear the background. He said that the Government had been very concerned and there had been considerable attempts on our part to elucidate the matter. The Prime Minister said that investigations had not identified the individual or individuals responsible for the shooting. He went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: There are different accounts of what happened. It seems unlikely, because of the difficulty and uncertain circumstances prevailing at the time, that the issue will ever be fully resolved.

I think that is acknowledged by those who currently are studying what was a most tragic matter. The fact is that it was a confused circumstance. As to the letter, it is not the practice of governments to table the contents of letters that have been exchanged between governments. I understand, therefore, that that letter will not be tabled. I understand that the substance of the matter had been conveyed to Tony Joyce's widow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I point out to the Minister that on 9 February 1980 Mr Peacock, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, said in a news release that President Kaunda was working on, and would provide, a report of the incident to the Australian Government. I wonder whether that report can be tabled.

—I am not aware of the specific report to which Senator Sibraa refers but I will look into the matter and seek details from the Minister in the other place. If I can provide any further information I will do so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Has the Minister noted an article in the Australian Financial Review of 4 November entitled 'NSW Government growth centre costs leap' in which the New South Wales Auditor-General is reported as indicating, firstly, that the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation is carrying real estate on its books at inflated values and, secondly, that the Corporation registered a loss of $7.3m in 1980-81-a 5.3 per cent increase on the previous year's figure of $6.95m, thus raising the Corporation's accumulated deficiency by 28 per cent from $25.8m to $33.12m? Finally, has the Minister noted the statement in the article that the comments of the New South Wales Auditor-General 'are particularly serious as they amount to a qualification of the group's balance sheet, meaning the accounts have failed to get a clean bill of health in a commercial sense'? What action has the Department of National Development and Energy taken, or does it intend to take, to safeguard the Commonwealth's financial interests in the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation in view of the disastrous comments made by the New South Wales Auditor-General?

—I did not see the article to which the honourable senator has referred. However, I will search it out, study it and if necessary look also at the New South Wales Auditor-General's report. But I do report to the Senate and to Senator Lajovic that last Friday I attended, with my two State colleagues, a meeting of the ministerial council of the Albury-Wodonga growth centre in Albury. We had before us for consideration the report of a review committee which was set up at my instigation and which comprised officers of the two State governments and the Federal Government. That report had been the subject of wide representations by the public. Indeed, after its submission 100 copies of it had been circulated and response invited. I have to report that, as a result of the deliberations on that day, the general findings of the review committee were adopted. That will mean a very considerable devolution of activity throughout the growth centre; that many of the functions of the Corporation will be undertaken essentially by local government itself; that a lot of infrastructure transfers will occur; that the enterprise itself will undertake a number of functions; and that land not essential for use by the Corporation will be disposed of in an orderly fashion. So, a thorough look will be taken at the whole of the procedures of the growth centre. I should stress that the Government is committed to the development of the Albury-Wodonga growth centre and that I am delighted that there should have been complete agreement between the three governments as to the procedures to be followed for the next three years.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question. Because of his fairness in granting me a pair during my illness I am sorry that the question cannot be more friendly. I refer to the legislation which the Government plans to introduce during the next session of Parliament validating the July 1981 and July 1982 increases in the oil levy. I ask whether the Leader of the Government will convey to the Cabinet and to the Prime Minister that the Senate remembers the speech which the Prime Minister made in Launceston three days before the last election and in which he promised:

QUESTION.PARA: If there are further significant increases (in oil prices) then the first priority of the Government will be to return that to the Australian family through the taxation mechanism or through family allowances.

Will the Leader of the Government further convey to the Cabinet that there is no way in which the Australian Democrats will vote for the validating legislation in the Senate unless these promised tax cuts or increases in family allowances are introduced either beforehand or simultaneously?

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of the question, I do not think it is my duty or responsibility to convey to my Government what other political parties may or may not do-that is for those parties to look to in the context of government-nor will we make package deals in that regard. The fact of the matter is that the Government's policy on import parity pricing is well known, well established and highly successful as, indeed, the frequent discoveries of both oil and gas in Australia are revealing. The Government has made clear its policies in that regard. The Government will be well aware of whatever statements it has made regarding revenues obtained in that area. The Government has been entirely solicitous of the families in Australia. Indeed, in the recent Budget it made a number of reforms in that regard. It will keep those in mind. The Government has one overwhelming principle in mind in all its budgeting, and that is that the best way to help the Australian families in terms of their welfare and prosperity is to keep inflation down and to bear down on interest rates. Nothing could be more beneficial to the Australian family than that. Of course, as honourable senators will know, in terms of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development comparisons Australia continues to be a front-runner in success in this regard.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. As the Leader of the Government, for his own good reasons, refuses to convey my request to the Cabinet, I ask whether he personally, as a leading member of the Cabinet, would regard the following statement as a firm, categoric, unequivocal promise:

QUESTION.PARA: If there are further significant increases (in oil prices) then the first priority of the Government will be to return that--
Namely, those additional funds-
to the Australian family through the taxation mechanism or through family allowances.
Does the Leader of the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —As we did.
—I always defer to the wisdom that comes out of Tasmania, Mr President. Does the Leader of the Government believe the foregoing statement to be a firm election undertaking?

—I am not aware of the full context from which Senator Chipp has quoted. I certainly will refresh my mind on it. The Government has made it clear that it will use moneys from oil revenues to increase benefits to families and, indeed, it has done so. As we are talking of extra money revenues, let me make it clear that in the course of this year the money revenues to the Budget will be in the order of $220m less than was foreshadowed in the Budget, due to the results of industrial unrest in the oil industry and the shipping industry. Even if the increase in oil revenue from the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries price rise from 1 January were taken into account, there would still be a shortfall of about $125m in oil revenue by 30 June. I think that should be kept in mind. So there will not be more revenue; there will be less than we foreshadowed in the Budget.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I draw attention to the recent disturbances and rioting in Noumea, culminating in the attempted destruction of a symbolic monument to the French presence in the Pacific. Has the Department of Foreign Affairs made a full assessment of the possibility of New Caledonia becoming an area of instability and the danger to Australian residents on the island? Is it aware of any moves by the French Government to meet at least some of the demands of the independence leaders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — There were street disturbances in Noumea following the annual Noumea street fair. These resulted in 90 arrests, mostly of Melanesian people. It is unlikely that any Australian tourists were involved, as far as the Department of Foreign Affairs is aware. I am not aware of any Australians being injured at that time. Whilst this occasion has given rise in previous years to small scale disturbances, the level of trouble this year has been considerably more serious. The French Secretary of State for Overseas Territories has called on all New Caledonians not to allow themselves to be drawn into unacceptable actions. He said that the French Government was open to dialogue and that it would make a political response to the Melanesian problem. On several occasions the Australian Government has repeated its support for the principles of self-determination and independence of the French Pacific territories. We hope that the South Pacific Forum countries' delegation to Paris later this year, to be led by the Fijian Prime Minister, will lead to movement by the French Government towards accepting independence as a desirable goal for the French territories. That is all the information I am able to supply on this matter. I will refer Senator Watson's question to the Minister and see whether he has any further response to make.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and follows the question asked earlier by Senator Sibraa. Does the Minister agree that one version of the circumstances of the death of Mr Tony Joyce was that he was shot while sitting in the back seat of a Zambian police car? When the Minister is checking the story with the Prime Minister to ascertain an answer to Senator Sibraa's question, will he also check on whether this version is supported by Australian diplomats who have sent official reports to the Department of Foreign Affairs in Canberra and whether those reports could be made available to the Senate?

—I have read a number of versions of the tragic death of Tony Joyce. I think that one of them suggested that he was, in fact, fatally injured when in a police car. I do not know the truth or otherwise of it. I do not know whether there is any evidence by diplomats or whether the diplomats themselves would be able to draw upon anything authoritative to support their views. I will bring Senator Button's question to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and invite his study of it.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to the recent decision of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to reject the plea of Gheorghe Viscreanu, the Romanian soccer player, to be allowed to stay in Australia and the fears expressed by members of the Romanian community in Melbourne that the undertakings which the Federal Government received from the Romanian Government that he would not suffer reprisals following his return to Romania would not be honoured. In view of the poor record of the Romanian Government on human rights matters, I ask the Minister: Firstly, will she give to the Parliament an undertaking that the Australian Government will keep in close contact with Viscreanu and the Romanian Government to see that the undertakings are honoured; and, secondly, will she forthwith report to the Australian Parliament any breaches of those undertakings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — That matter was given very careful consideration by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs before the decision was made not to grant refugee status to Mr Gheorghe Viscreanu. Recognising the matters raised by Senator Missen, I advise that it is a fact that some sections of the Romanian community in Australia have expressed doubts about Mr Viscreanu's future well-being. We have, through the Australian Embassy in Belgrade which is accredited to Romania, made arrangements to maintain regular contact with the Romanian authorities and for the Australian officials to seek to visit Mr Viscreanu from time to time. The well-being of this young man is of concern to us, but his application for refugee status did not have within it the usual provisions concerning actions which are expected to be undertaken at the time that such status is granted.

ANSWER.PARA: However, as Senator Missen has expressed concern with regard to the human rights of this man in the country concerned, I assure Senator Missen that the arrangements I have outlined have been made. Also, I will ask the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to consider the suggestions made in the question of Senator Missen to see whether there is any further action that we believe ought to be taken. If I can report anything further from time to time I will see that the Senate is advised. Before we asked the young man to leave, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs did obtain from the Romanian Government an assurance that Mr Viscreanu would not suffer in any way. That assurance was given but, as I said, continued contact will be made through our diplomatic officials. If further action is needed, I will see that Senator Missen is advised of any further action taken by the Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Veterans' Affairs or the Government requested the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Attorney-General's Department or any Commonwealth law officer to consider making changes to the Repatriation Act in light of the recent High Court decision in the 'Perth widow' case? What is the Government's best estimate of the extra call that will be made on Commonwealth funds if the Repatriation Act remains unamended as to the onus of proof provisions? Assuming an answer to that question, what arrangements has the Government in train to ensure that moneys are available to meet its responsibilities to veterans as determined by Parliament under the present Act?

—With regard to the question of whether a request has been made to the Attorney-General's Department in connection with any changes that might be contemplated in respect of section 47 of the Repatriation Act, no such request has been transmitted to that Department since the handing down of the decision by the High Court on, I think, 16 October. However, a request has been made to that Department for a paper on the options that might be available to the Government in connection with any action it may take. As regards the best estimate of the costs involved following the decision made by the High Court, unfortunately I am in no clear position to be able to indicate such costs. The best information available to me indicates that this may be of the order of some hundreds of millions of dollars, but it would depend entirely upon the decisions taken by individual tribunals and boards of review from time to time. Therefore, I am unable to answer the honourable senator's question in any direct way. With regard to moneys being made available, of course, it is always the Government's obligation-clearly, the Government accepts its obligation -to meet its commitments under any law that is passed by the Parliament.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. When was the reference for the options paper sent to the Attorney-General's Department? Secondly, when the terms of reference relating to that options paper were sent to the Department, was the possibility of an amendment to the onus of proof provisions excluded from the options to be considered?
—I would need to take on notice the question as to the exact date. I cannot recall that offhand.
—Before or after the decision?
—No, as I have said, all matters were considered after the decision. I believe the terms of reference were very general, that is, canvassing all options that the Government might consider further.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and concerns the unfair lack of funds to Queensland from the Federal Government for the specific purpose of road construction and maintenance. Is the Minister aware of the horrific road toll of 507 persons killed on Queensland roads so far this year, most of which have occurred on notorious country roads? Does the Minister not agree that such a toll would be greatly reduced if Queensland's roads were not in such dire need of upgrading and repair because of lack of funds from the Federal Government? Having already outlined in previous speeches to this chamber the fact that Queensland is being severely disadvantaged in road funding allocations compared with other States--
—Did you write that, or did Alan Callaghan?

—Senator Walsh has got that on his brain, I am afraid. I heard an honourable senator say: 'What brain?' I ask the Minister: When can we expect to be given some justice and a fair go in this situation?

—I am advised by the Minister for Transport that he is, indeed, aware of the very large difficulty with and problems on the roads in Queensland and in fact regrets, as do all honourable senators and Government members, such tragic loss of life on those roads. I am sure that Senator Bjelke-Petersen would acknowledge that road accidents occur for a multiplicity of reasons. Whilst the Minister does not have the details of individual accidents, he feels that it would be reasonable to assume that some of the fatalities that have occurred in Queensland from time to time may have been due to bad roads. The deficiencies of the road system in Queensland have, I believe, been due largely to problems with the State Government not allocating sufficient funds from time to time for the construction and upkeep of the roads generally. However, the Minister has advised that figures he received recently show that Queensland and, to a lesser extent, New South Wales have fared badly under present funding arrangements for roads and that he is giving consideration to requests in respect of a more equitable distribution of those funds.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, refers to the present dispute between the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association and his Department. I ask my question in an attempt to ascertain why the dispute has reached the state it has. Is it a fact that the dispute has been in progress for more than 12 months and that the bans referred to have been in place for some 12 months? In this time has the Minister taken any part in consultation or conciliation processes with the union? As the staff has taken this matter seriously and repeatedly warned over the 12 months of the deteriorating situation, why is it only now that the Government has taken the matter seriously and introduced suspensions which, inevitably, will exacerbate the present situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the dispute which is at present afflicting my Department does arise from bans which have been imposed in a small number of offices over a period of some 12 months. Those bans have applied to work with respect to the recovery of overpayments, certain statistical collections and, in a limited number of cases, the servicing of inquiries involving members of parliament or the Minister. The matter has been approached with patience. A number of complaints have been made by the union which are alleged to lie at the heart of the dispute-complaints about accommodation, training and staff ceilings. With respect to all those matters the Department has given serious attention to areas of concern. For example, the Government has allocated additional moneys within the last few months to ease accommodation problems in some offices where it was certainly thought there were grounds for complaint and concern. Action by the Government is continuously being taken with respect to training. But as recently as about a week ago the Public Service Board agreed that part of the temporary ceiling cover, which was found not to be necessary for the continued servicing of the health benefits function which we have recently assumed, should be maintained by the Department during this year to enable us to undertake a greater training initiative.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to staff ceilings, the Government has taken a very careful line in the Department of Social Security. The matter has been reviewed on a number of occasions. Staff ceilings, which were around 9,000, when we allow for adjustment of functions in 1976, stand at around 11,500 today with additional temporary cover being available for the recently assumed functions and for training. As I indicated a few minutes ago, training is to be continued. So far as the bans are concerned, the union did seek a meeting with me and I indicated in writing in August last that I would be prepared to meet with the union, although in general I regard matters such as conditions in and the administration of my Department as being the responsibility of those charged under the legislation with the administration of the Department. Given that some decisions of the Government such as staff ceiling decisions impinge on that, I indicated that I was prepared to meet with the union but not while bans were in place.

So far as the recent activity is concerned, I think it was some weeks ago that notice was given by the Director-General that the bans would not be tolerated beyond this week and the request was made that they should be lifted. In fact bans are not applicable in Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia, Tasmania, the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory. It is only in New South Wales and Victoria that relatively small meetings involving a few hundred officers have voted to maintain the bans. Where bans have been applied there have been stand-downs over recent days and as a result there have been some walk-outs in sympathy. The number of officers affected by the walk-outs and bans totals about 1,000, with a considerably smaller number being involved today. Of course, I very much regret that we have reached a point at which a small proportion of our officers are affected in this way. I understand that it is extremely unhelpful to our clientele and to our achieving the welfare objectives of this Government.

In fact, the bans have been applying for 12 months. We cannot have a situation in which people simply choose to do the work that they believe they are entitled to do to make their point. The Government, after a very patient approach, was of the view that stand-downs should occur. They have occurred. I trust that the normal good sense of the Department's officers will be manifested at tomorow's meetings and that there will be a return to work. I stress that the great bulk of the Department's officers, both in the past and over the last few days, have loyally served the interests of the Australians that they are employed to serve. I am sorry that a small minority of officers have caused the disruption which is inconveniencing some of our beneficiaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is it not a fact that, even prior to the bans being applied, the Department's senior administrative officers in New South Wales would not consult with the unions? When consultations were held in Victoria it was found that in fact an extra 90 staff were needed. What will the Minister do if the dispute does extend to other States as has been suggested may occur as a result of meetings in other States today?

—The Government and the administration of my Department are always open to a reasoned case on the staffing requirements of the Department. Those avenues are open to the union. It is only in circumstances in which the union adopts what are in effect stand-over tactics that we cannot do business. I very much regret that there are difficulties in doing business in some areas at the moment. I trust that will come to a speedy end.

—I have a question for the Minister representing the Minister for Defence about the recurring crashes of Iroquois helicopters of the Australian defence forces. Does the Minister have any information as to the nature of the faults that have led to the recent crashes and to the grounding of the Iroquois helicopters? Do the faults appear to be the result of metal fatigue? Have helicopters of this type that are in service with other air forces developed similar faults? Can the Minister say how many of these helicopters are still in service in the Australian defence forces and whether any investigation is being made as to their remaining life?

—I am advised that investigation into the two recent Royal Australian Air Force UH1 Iroquois helicopter accidents has not revealed a common cause. The accident involving helicopter A2-1023 at Williamtown on 19 August is still under investigation and the B model Iroquois remain grounded while the investigation continues. Evidence indicates a possible problem in the tail rotor control system. The most recent accident involving A2-380 at Rockhampton on 30 October was caused by a technical defect in the tail rotor drive system. All other RAAF Iroquois helicopters have been checked for similar problems but to date no defects have been found. The other recent Iroquois helicopter accident was a mid-air collision between two Royal New Zealand Air Force helicopters in the Shoalwater Bay training area on 23 October this year during Kangaroo 81. I think I was also asked how many such helicopters we have. I do not have that information immediately. I will seek it and let Senator Lewis have it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I direct to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, relates to a question I asked him on 15 October 1981 concerning the statement by that distinguished Australian of Polish origin, Professor George Zubrzycki, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: For a bloodless revolution to succeed, people outside Poland have to give moral and economic support. We must show civic courage in supporting the Polish people.

I asked then what commitment had been made or was being made by the Government in respect of economic aid to the Polish people and what form that aid would take. The Minister did respond sympathetically and indicated that he would give a substantial reply. When he does I wonder whether he could address his mind to a further question concerning community aid to Poland. As he would appreciate, a number of committees throughout Australia are attempting to develop a situation where community aid can be provided to the people of Poland. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Gietzelt proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The lack of concern by the Government regarding the effect of the accelerating global arms race.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the global arms race and the failure to make any progress in disarmament generally throughout the world has created in world public opinion a sense of unease and concern that is rising almost daily. Almost six months ago in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald headed 'A man of peace forecasts tragic finish in weapons race', it was reported that the former United States of America Ambassador to Moscow, George Kennan, said that his Government had gone mad. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: After studying United States-USSR relations for 53 years, he was certain the two great super-powers were on a collision course. Not just a war, but a nuclear war.

There is no doubt that public opinion is growing apprehensive and fearful at what seems to be a headlong and inevitable drift towards an unwinnable nuclear war. We did not heed his remarks. In an article published only several days ago it is interesting to find the following statement:
Washington-Three nuclear scientists have warned that the US is headed towards a nuclear war under the misguided assumption that such a conflict can be won.

'The US and the Soviet Union are on the path to nuclear war', Professor Henry Kendall said at a news conference yesterday when plans were announced for a national convocation to be staged on 150 college campuses on November 11 on the threat of nuclear war. 'We want to shake the country out of its indifference to the drift toward nuclear war', Professor Kendall added. 'Scientists have to share their knowledge of the nuclear peril and speak out about the steps that have to be taken to control it. The risk of such a war is real, and it is increasing.'

His remarks were added to at the same time by Mr Herbert Scoville, the president of the Arms Control Association and technical director of the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project during the post-war atomic tests. He said that President Reagan's concept of a window of vulnerability was misleading and dangerous. He continued:

The idea that the US has a weak nuclear deterrent force is just absolutely false. The idea that we are weak and must become stronger in order to negotiate with the Soviets is just an excuse to get more weapons.

The Australian Labor Party believes that the issue of nuclear war transcends all other issues facing humanity. Therefore we believe that there ought to be a debate on this issue. I remind the Senate that on the last day of sitting of the House of Representatives the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) tabled the report of the Australian delegation to the 1981 session of the United Nations Committee on Disarmament in Geneva. Honourable senators will see that the report underlines the main features of the matter of public importance we are discussing today. The report dealt with a number of issues: Nuclear disarmament and the cessation of the nuclear arms race; effective international arrangements to assure non-nuclear weapons states against the use or threat of nuclear weapons; and a comprehensive program of disarmament. But, as the Australian delegation's report stated, there was a 'lack of progress on the item of prime importance to Australia; a comprehensive test ban and inconclusive work on other agenda items'. The report continued:

It must also be recorded that the general atmosphere in the Committee has been more political than in the past, with much time devoted to political advocacy and correspondingly less to actual substantive negotiations. In the view of the Australian delegation these unfortunate developments in 1981 are attributable to factors external to the Committee. There are major substantive difficulties yet to be resolved in connection with each of the agenda items, but there are also serious prospects of making progress as soon as the general international climate so permits.

In the Committee's estimation it was hostage to the tense international situation and its work in forwarding the process of peace and disarmament would get nowhere until that situation of international tension, distrust and rivalry was changed.

There is no doubt that the climate of international relations is very cool and very bad indeed. This has undoubtedly been exacerbated by the backward and cold war remarks made over the last 12 months of the Reagan Administration in the United States. This brings me to the first point of today's matter of public importance-the tension heightening role of the new United States Government. Over the weekend just past we heard reports of statements from the Reagan Administration suggesting the possibility of a so-called limited nuclear war in Europe. In this case we understand that, according to reports in the Melbourne Age of 7 November, the United States Secretary of State, Alexander Haig, told a Senate Foreign Relations Committee meeting that there were 'contingency plans in the NATO doctrine to fire a nuclear weapon as a warning for demonstrative purposes'. Washington has currently got its propaganda wires a bit crossed because Secretary of Defense Weinberger then denied that such a plan existed. It has become clear that such a proposition is and has been within the context of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation strategy. This is even more alarming when taken alongside President Reagan's statement of 21 October this year in the New York Times. He is reported as saying that he 'could see where you have the exchange of tactical (nuclear) weapons against troops in the field without it bringing either one of the major powers to pushing the button'. Again, in this case President Reagan was referring to Europe as the potential site for this limited use of nuclear weapons and, of course, Europe sees itself as expendable in this super-power rivalry.

All governments in Europe, regardless of their political colour, are apprehensive and concerned, and why would they not be when it is admitted that the two super-powers themselves have 16,000 million tonnes of TNT which is equivalent to one and a quarter billion Hiroshima bombs? That is the state of the arms race that exists in the world today.

We have confusion from one of the major powers not clearly defining how it sees the current disagreements and difficulties between the super-powers. We have President Reagan referring to Europe as the potential site for this limited use of nuclear weapons. In current thinking it is clear that the United States is building up to the stage where it is willing to use nuclear weapons in the European theatre against Soviet and Soviet-backed forces. It believes that this use of a nuclear armoury will be controlled and that there is no chance of such a conflict escalating into a full-scale nuclear holocaust. In taking this position the Reagan Administration has finally abandoned the old concept of a nuclear balance between the major powers, the concept of mutually assured destruction commonly described in strategic and military terms as MAD. Surely, it is aptly and appropriately named MAD. Under this concept both the United States and the Soviet Union, subject to each other's nuclear arsenal, would destroy each other in a nuclear conflagration. Therefore, neither country would make a move.

Now President Reagan believes nuclear war can be controlled. Further, he believes that with a sufficiently developed nuclear capacity an all-out nuclear war can be won by the side with an efficient first-strike capability. Hence he believes there is a need to develop on the one hand tactical nuclear weapons such as the neutron bomb, which can be used in supposedly small-scale conflicts, and on the other hand strategic, large-scale weapons such as the MX or Cruise missiles which aim to knock out completely the Soviet armoury. This is in contradiction to the expressed view of President Brezhnev, which must be rejected of course by the conservative viewpoint, that the Soviet Government pledges itself never to be the first government to press the button, that there will be no winner in a nuclear conflagration. Today I contend-the experts are behind me-that the Reagan concept of limited nuclear war is a false concept, an impossibility. With the extent of nuclear weapons available to both nuclear powers, not forgetting the nuclear cababilities of many of the smaller powers, there is no doubt that the small-scale use of nuclear weapons in Europe, as has been suggested by President Reagan and his aides, would soon develop into an all-out nuclear war. Moreover, the development of tactical and strategic nuclear weapons such as those announced this year by President Reagan can only further the race towards the building of an even more horrifying store of potential destruction.

Let us look for a moment at some of the comments by people who should know something about these matters. Admiral Gene La Roque, formerly a senior member of the nuclear planning group which is charged with the task of assessing United States and NATO nuclear requirements, earlier this year, about the time that George Kennan made his comments, said:
Some military men feel that a nuclear war once begun, can be controlled and limited even within the theatre. But I have never seen a reasonable plan to control a nuclear war.
Honourable senators will remember the late Lord Mountbatten and his comment:
I cannot imagine a situation in which nuclear weapons would be used as battlefield weapons without the conflagration spreading.

Dr George B. Kistiakowsky, a science adviser to United States Presidents Eisenhower, Kennedy and Johnson and one who took part in the development of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombs, backs up this statement. He recently claimed:
As an inevitable consequence of a limited nuclear war between nuclear superpowers, the holocaust would come.
I have referred to George Kennan, the famous United States diplomat, foreign affairs adviser to successive presidents and ambassador to the Soviet Union. He is reported to have said:
Every President of this country, from Dwight Eisenhower to Jimmy Carter, has tried to remind us that there could be no such thing as victory in a war fought with (nuclear) weapons.

These are all moderates, conservatives, military men, scientists and diplomats saying these things. Many of these things have been said in the United States itself. These people make it clear that the arms race is, unless halted, a race to destruction. They underline the absolute foolishness of the current United States Government policies. Is it any wonder that in past months we have seen nearly two million people demonstrating in the streets of the various capitals of Europe against the arms race and the threat it poses to peace in that region? Is it surprising, for example, that in the last two years the membership of Britain's Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament has increased tenfold, to 30,000? There is no doubt that there is mass apprehension concerning the escalation of the arms race, particularly the nuclear arms race, and the aggressive policies of the super-powers.

The current arms race has five features that I wish to discuss. First and foremost at the moment is the new development of United States nuclear capacity. Despite the fact that President Reagan has been forced to reduce planned military increases for budgetary reasons, he has announced the go-ahead for the following: The construction of the high radiation neutron bomb; the development of the B1 bomber to replace the current B52s by 1986; the development of 100 multi-warhead MX missiles for deployment in existing missile silos by 1984-and those of us who saw that reported on television were very much concerned indeed; the construction of large, more accurate sea-launched Trident II missiles by 1989; the upgrading of international air surveillance; and the deployment of Pershing II and Cruise missiles by NATO forces in Europe. This represents probably the most substantial development of United States arms since the cold war period of the 1950s.

Of course, I can anticipate the response of the conservative opposition when faced with these facts. 'What about the Russians; what about the Red menace?' they will cry. In effect, that was the defence offered by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) of the United States President's decision to go ahead with the neutron bomb. I should make it clear that the Australian Labor Party does not defend the Soviet Union's position. Let me be unequivocal about that. The super-powers have contributed to world tensions, but to devote all of one's criticism to the Soviets while ignoring the United States arms build-up is to be blind and hypocritical. Today it is the United States that leads the arms race, and historically it has always been so. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table which underlines my point. It is taken from an article by Andrew Mack in the October issue of the Asian Defence Journal entitled 'The Soviet Threat: Reality or Myth?' It shows that the United States leads, and has always led, in the arms race in terms of innovation. If one examines the figures in the table it becomes clear that the United States leads in terms of total nuclear warheads as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Secondly, we should nevertheless point to the Soviet's upgrading of its own nuclear capacity. In this light, its deployment of 250 SS-20 missiles, each containing three nuclear warheads aimed specifically at European targets, is of special note. Also, the Soviet's untenable occupation of Afghanistan has contributed, for a whole number of reasons, to world tension. Thirdly, the breakdown in the SALT II negotiations exemplifies the tenseness of the situation. Once again the blame must be laid at the door of Mr Reagan because, despite the signing of the agreement, his Administration and the United States Congress have refused to ratify SALT II. Afghanistan cannot justifiably be used to halt this important step in the peace progress. Mr Kennan makes the point that the Soviets have lost more than they have ever gained as a result of that intervention.

SPEECH.PARA: My fourth point relates to the failure of the strategic arms limitation talks. President Reagan will not go ahead with arms limitation talks until he feels that the United States is in a position of real arms superiority; hence the current United States arms build-up. That is hardly, we believe, a way to negotiate peace. Fifthly, side by side with the arms race of the super-powers, we face a huge arms build-up around the world. As Time magazine noted in its issue of 26 October, this involves a nuclear arms build-up in countries such as China, Israel, Pakistan, France, Libya, Iraq, South Africa and elsewhere, as well as a conventional arms build-up in countries too numerous to name. It is a build-up that is being facilitated by the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. According to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, the USSR supplies 30 per cent of arms sales to the Third World while the United States supplies some 45 per cent.

How has the Government responded to the international arms situation today? It has responded irresponsibly and one-sidedly. There is no doubt that one of Australia's most important alliances is its alliance with the United States. The Labor Party recognises that fact and believes that we should use that relationship creatively. The present Government does not do that at all. It merely kow-tows to every move of the United States Administration. Friendships should never be on the basis of one country meekly following the strongest.

There is a relatively new United States Government, one which, as I have already noted, has changed considerably the course of United States foreign and arms policies. Yet there is no flexibility in our Government's approach. Its approach remains one of passiveness and mere acceptance. For example, when President Reagan moved ahead with the development of the neutron bomb, the response of our Prime Minister was one of unequivocal support. The response of the Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, to reports of renewed talks between the United States and Soviet foreign ministers due for November was similar. According to the Australian of 27 September, all he could do was talk about 'Soviet expansionism'. That was hardly a suitable response to what are probably the only positive developments on the arms limitation front at the moment. We in the Labor Party, on the other hand, welcome and encourage the talks while recognising the transgressions in which both sides are engaged.
When China set off its nuclear missile in the Pacific last year, the Prime Minister said:
Having in mind the capacities of other super powers, it is natural that China, as a large, great and proud nation would want similar capacities.

That is exactly the mentality of the arms race. Its philosophy is: 'If the other side has it, we want it too'. This is endorsed by our Prime Minister. The disarmament policy of this Government is in reality a shrug of the shoulders. It says: 'Go ahead. We won't protest; we won't bring any pressure to bear'. Government spokesmen in this debate will no doubt quote the Prime Minister's statement to the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament in July 1978 when he said:

The first focus of the program of action for arms control and disarmament must be on issues of nuclear arms control. My Government's position is clear and unequivocal. We oppose further escalation of the nuclear arms race. We oppose the spread of nuclear weapons.

First, the nuclear weapons powers must take effective action to limit and reduce their nuclear arsenals. Second, there must be an end to nuclear testing in all environments. Third, the international non-proliferation system must be strengthened.
