TALK.START.PARA: —As the voice fades in the distance, I remind the Senate and the people of Australia that we are debating a matter of public importance relating to 'the effect of the accelerating global arms race'. I draw attention to what I think is one of the most astounding speeches I have heard in this place-the speech by Senator Gietzelt. The key to his speech was a sentence which he repeated, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: Today it is the United States that leads the arms race and historically it has always been so.

He repeated that statement; they were his words. In fact, his speech for the first 13 minutes was an attack upon the United States of America and the American arms buildup. Then, with seven minutes remaining, he suddenly remembered that he had better say something about the Soviet Union.
Let us test this situation. Senator Gietzelt's thesis is:
Today it is the United States that leads the arms race and historically it has always been so.

The people of Australia ought to know the facts. The facts are that for a decade the spending of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on strategic nuclear arms has been three times that of the United States. In the same period, Soviet spending on conventional weapons has been double that of the United States. The armed forces of the Soviet Union outnumber those of the United States by more than two to one. While the United States has replaced some of its land-based missiles with the multiple warhead, the Minuteman III, the United States today has the same number of intercontinental ballistic missiles that it had in 1967. The United States has deployed no additional nuclear ballistic missile carrying submarines since 1967. The United States has deployed no new heavy strategic bombers since 1962. Indeed, the B52 bomber fleet has been reduced from 935 in 1956 to less than 350. On the side of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, over 300 SS18s, each with multiple warheads, are now deployed. Each of these is capable of carrying at least 10 warheads and each missile has a destructive capacity exceeding 200 times that of the Hiroshima bomb. The Soviet Union last year launched the largest strategic missile submarine in the world, the Typhoon. Recently a Russian submarine was found within the waters of a Swedish naval base, purportedly carrying nuclear weapons. The Russians have consistently outspent the United States in the area of military hardware and have clearly pursued, and continue to pursue, an aggressive foreign policy which does not stop at the occupation of independent countries.
Against those facts-they are capable of proof-the whole of Senator Gietzelt's speech was completely unfounded. He said:
Today it is the United States that leads the arms race and historically it has always been so.

Indeed, he built up a series of concepts, putting into President Reagan's mouth words that do not exist. Of course, America does not believe that anyone can win a nuclear war. Of course, that is a rejection. It is not true that America is willingly pursuing a collision towards war. America today is carrying the burden of peace for the free world. That is something we ought to be supporting; that is something we ought to be praising, not sneering at and distorting. It is no use trying to put words into President Reagan's mouth because he has decided upon the construction of the neutron bomb in a limited capacity. The fact of the matter is that the Soviet armed forces, both in manpower and in armour on the ground, so greatly outnumber the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation forces that the capacity of the Soviets to overrun Western Europe and, indeed, the free world is immense. In the view of the Americans the only way to stop that is to have effective deterrents. If the armed forces are outnumbered two to one in a conventional way, there must be deterrents. The United States is not an aggressive force. The United States is a country which, like the United Kingdom of the past, is now carrying the burden of peace for the world on its shoulders. I remind the Senate of the enormous distortion of Senator Gietzelt's speech. He deliberately misconstrued the size, nature and growth of the Soviets and, indeed, almost forgot their existence, in pouring out his vindictive attack against America. One of the sad things about the Opposition is how much its members can show and reveal their hatred of all that is American. It is tragic that this should be so.

I turn to the substance of this matter. The Government shares the concern expressed in the community at the current state of international tension and at the prospects for escalation of the arms race. The need for practical measures on arms control in order to restrain the arms race is greater today than at any time in world history, but the need to protect the free world from war today is greater than at any time in world history. We do not get protection from war simply by ignoring the buildup of potential opponents. We do not get protection unless there are policies on security. The international political climate is difficult and grows steadily more difficult. Events in Afghanistan and Poland illustrate the problems we face. The Government maintains, nevertheless, its strong support for the goal of disarmament and the negotiation of balanced and verifiable measures of arms control. The Government continues to give the highest priority to preventing the spread of nuclear weapons. There can be no question of our outstanding support for the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and the measures deriving from it. We are actively promoting the conclusion of a treaty outlawing the testing of nuclear weapons by all states in all environments.

Our commitment to disarmament and arms control goals not only is pursued in the interest of world stability but also is firmly based upon Australia's national interests. A stable world is important to us all. When we face the continuing development of military preparedness by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the Warsaw Pact countries, and unless those countries can be joined with us and our allies in genuine disarmament, we must balance our ultimate goal of world disarmament with preparedness against the exercise of military power by others. It is to be recognised that the present international climate is not favourable to the achieving of balanced and verifiable arms control treaties. A firm climate of confidence between states is an essential basis for progress towards agreements on arms control. Yet the trends in Soviet power growth continue unabated.

So concerned is our ally, the United States of America, that it recently took the unprecedented step of releasing a booklet by Caspar Weinberger entitled Soviet Military Power. I direct the attention of the Senate and the public to that booklet. It shows that from a defensive Soviet military establishment 20 years ago there has been a movement to a development which possesses strong offensive capabilities today. The booklet, written in low key, clearly documents development in a way which shows how the Soviet Union has systematically eliminated its vulnerabilities, improved its ability to attack swiftly and extended its naval range and air force punch. In the West we see well-intentioned protest movements opposing military preparedness; yet those protest movements ignore the fact that peace can come only if both sides desist. It is not sufficient for one country or group of countries to lay down its arms in the face of an increasing threat from others.

It is regrettable that those who sincerely seek disarmament may be forced to remain prepared. Australia has been very active in promoting disarmament and it is not a cause for apology that we should also have to look to our preparedness. Indeed, military preparedness ought to be-on occasions it seems to be-a bipartisan concept. Mr Hayden made it clear in recent remarks on defence that he subscribes to this view and the Australian community at large accepts the necessity for our defence to be strong. All that said, it simply remains to give some examples of the Government's concern to pursue the ultimate goal of disarmament. The first Special Session on Disarmament of the United Nations General Assembly took place in June 1978 and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) represented Australia, as Senator Gietzelt mentioned. This is an indication of how seriously this Government views disarmament: The Prime Minister made a major speech in which he emphasised Australia's goals of disarmament. It included three main points. I use his words:

The nuclear weapons powers must take effective action to limit and reduce their nuclear arsenals . . . There must be an end to nuclear testing in all environments . . . The international non-proliferation system must be strengthened . . .

Australia is a member of the United Nations Comittee on Disarmament-and an active member. The Committee is a single multilateral negotiating forum in the disarmament field. On 29 October the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) tabled in Parliament the report of the Australian delegation to the 1981 Session of the Committee on Disarmament. In doing so, he noted that the report provided a readily accessible and authoritative account of the major disarmament issues being discussed internationally. He said that he believed the report would be a positive contribution to discussions on disarmament, but observed that the main reasons for the unfavourable international climate in regard to successful negotiation of disarmament and arms control measures were, largely, the Soviet Union's extensive armament program, the instability which the Soviet Union had created by its invasion and occupation of Afghanistan and the Soviet Union's support for Vietnam's invasion and occupation of Kampuchea. Mr Street welcomed the discussions on the theatre nuclear forces in Europe which are to begin shortly between the United States and the Soviet Union.

Australia is preparing actively for the second Special Session on Disarmament, which is to be held in 1982. At the second special session we are hopeful of significant progress being made in the three goals already mentioned and we will be continuing to promote the development of a comprehensive convention banning chemical weapons. Honourable senators will be only too well aware of recent indications that chemical weapons have been used in Afghanistan. This indicates the urgency of drawing up a comprehensive and fully verifiable treaty. The Australian Government's opposition to the testing of nuclear weapons by France in the Pacific is well known and has been consistent for many years.

Let me repeat that disarmament cannot be one-sided. Action by the Soviet Union could provide a basis for greater international confidence and have a very welcome effect on the international climate. Let me illustrate this, as I have done, by referring to the enormous buildup of arms by the Soviet Union. I again remind the Senate of this book. I must say that while listening to Senator Gietzelt I was mindful of a comment by Michael Barnard in the Age newspaper recently. The article was headed: 'Not so much doves as lemmings'. It stated:
And what's more (to resume last week's theme) there is in the West today an ultimately suicidal public tendency to suspect the very worst of our friends and the very best of our enemies.

Nothing could have illustrated that more than the speech today by Senator Gietzelt. He spent 13 minutes on a virulent attack upon America and in saying that the arms race is the creation of the Americans. In the remaining seven minutes he reminded himself that the Soviet Union existed. Then, again, we heard the words that the United States leads the arms race today and historically always has done so. That is an utterly false statement indeed on which to base an utterly false attack. Michael Barnard went on to say:
The clarity and reasoning which encourages consensus and enables political or any other form of leadership to function effectively is largely gone.

A blinding example of this failure to comprehend, of public susceptibility to misrepresentation, is the response to President Reagan's recent remarks on nuclear warfare. Asked whether he believed it possible for there to be a tactical nuclear exchange without it necessarily escalating to full-scale strategic nuclear warfare, the President replied, ''I don't honestly know'', and then proceeded to outline a contingency in which he considered a limited exchange might occur.
The article states:

In very short time the canard was around-especially in Western Europe where Left-liberal media, unilateral disarmers and Soviet ''peace'' fronts had a field day-that a grossly insensitive US was prepared to fight a limited nuclear war at Europe's expense.

Nothing could describe the error, the distortion, of Senator Gietzelt's speech more than that. Let me put this together. Clearly, Senator Gietzelt's speech was built upon the premise that the United States was leading, moving ahead and the pacesetter in the arms race and had always been. I systemically set out to describe the fact that for a decade the spending of the USSR on strategic nuclear arms had been three times that of the United States; that in the same period Soviet spending on conventional weapons had been double that of the United States; that the armed forces of the Soviet Union outnumber those of the United States by more than two to one; that while the United States had been steadying its number of projectiles there had been a significant increase in the number in Russia; and that there had been a buildup in the Soviet Union's naval fleet and air force. All those things are in contradiction of what Senator Gietzelt said.

The fact of the matter is that the two mighty powers today, the USSR and the USA, are unhappily and tragically for the world locked into a condition which has been described as peace by mutual terror. I refer to peace maintained by the threat by one to the other of retaliation after the first strike in nuclear warfare. One of the ugliest concepts mankind can have is that one has to defend oneself by making it impossible for the other fellow to obtain total victory at the first strike. If that is so, it is necessary for America-it is necessary for the free world also for whose defence America takes the weight of the burden-to build itself up to be a force capable of deterrence.

I reject entirely any suggestion that America has an aggressive role in this world or that it will unwittingly provoke war by its actions. America has not caused the Afghanistan situation. America is not causing the problems in Vietnam and Kampuchea. America is not destabilising many parts of the world. The fact is that the Soviet influence throughout the world is aimed at destabilisation. I have pointed out that Australia is pledged to nuclear disarmament; that is, to restrict the arms buildup, to achieve arms limitation and to ensure that nuclear weapons do not proliferate throughout the world. We are one of the main countries in the world which lays down stringent rules against proliferation of nuclear arms and weapons. It is an astounding situation that a member of the Labor Party can mount a speech which, except in latter moments of repentance, entirely puts the blame upon America and sees America as the great pacesetter in arms. This goes against all the facts of modern day history. America has a tremendous burden to carry in ensuring the peace of the world. We should be advising it, helping it and being a friend, albeit a critical friend if necessary. We should never forget that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the accelerating global arms race. In dealing with that subject I do not want to enter into a discussion about goodies and baddies. We are all very good at that; we learnt it in the Boy Scouts. We should not be carrying on that sort of debate in the Senate in 1981. Of course, Senator Carrick is a past master at it. What we are concerned about is the very low profile which the Australian Government adopts in relation to peace and disarmament. If we are to have a serious debate about it, it is ridiculous for the Leader of the Government to say that the United States Government, for example, is not guilty of any kind of aggressive action. Of course the United States Government is guilty of aggressive actions in international affairs. It was guilty of aggressive actions in Guatemala. It still props up in Guatemala a corrupt and extremely regressive government, and it does so with military force. It is guilty of at least partial aggression in El Salvador, an aggression which has aroused the condemnation and criticism of two countries, Canada and France, which Australia said were essential to the Sinai peacekeeping force. They have a view which is totally different from that of the United States Government on the situation in El Salvador. The Australian Government has no view at all because although the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is concerned to project himself as a world statesman he does not have a world view on these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The sort of thing which precipitates a debate of this kind is growing community concern about world peace. I speak perhaps only for myself when I say that I am immensely concerned about these matters. I am concerned about the team of geriatrics in the Kremlin whose positions on these issues were determined in the 1950s and still remain the same. I am concerned every time I see President Reagan on television. He might scare the hell out of the Russians but he also scares the hell out of me. I am very concerned that the President of the United States should hold some of the views which he apparently holds. We in Australia would be very thoughtful and careful if we recognised that fact. We should be concerned about the lack of a world view by the United States on these matters. We should be concerned in this Parliament that our Government does not follow the United States up the same drain pipe on every conceivable occasion.

Senator Carrick in his contribution to this debate gave no evidence really of Australia's international involvement in disarmament questions. He confused the issues of military preparedness and disarmament-military preparedness for what; disarmament for what? They are the questions which have to be considered and they cannot be glibly confused as they were by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I think also it is quite extraordinary to say in a debate of this kind that we know what we are up against because of Afghanistan and Poland. If Senator Carrick knows what we are up against because of Afghanistan and Poland I would have expected a more intelligent approach from the Australian Government. Because the approach from the Australian Government was to try to stop us participating in the Olympic Games. That has had very little effect on what has happened in Afghanistan. In relation to Poland, I would have expected a more thoughtful and generous approach from the Australian Government than the one which has so far been shown.

It is hardly extravagant in my view to regard arms limitations as a matter of life and death. This Government's record on these questions does not match its rhetoric at any time. There is a lot of talk, not much action. I think we have to look at the size of the problem before we determine an appropriate attitude for a country the size of Australia to take. In 1980 Russia and the United States spent over $200,000m on armaments. With the election of the Thatcher Government in England in 1979 and the Reagan Government in the United States in 1980, defence expenditure has risen sharply in both of those countries. The defence priorities, not the expenditure, are in a sense the most alarming thing. All three governments have a predeliction for new machinery but there is evidence to suggest that in many cases this is sheer folly. The Reagan Administration is pressing ahead with the MX missile system. This is alleged to be an urgent priority because the Russians could destroy existing Minuteman silos in a first strike and so go unpunished by the United States. That presupposes, as the British Guardian pointed out a couple of weeks ago, an efficiency in the Russians beyond credibility. There are 1,052 missile silos containing the Minuteman missile. If ten of those silos were untouched-only ten-by a Russian pre-emptive strike the United States could still deliver a 10 megaton strike on the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics from those ten silos alone. That is, it could deliver 666 times the force of explosion which took place at Hiroshima. The United States would still have that sort of nuclear capacity if that situation arose. So if we talk about punishment in a nuclear context, which seems to me to be a crazy sort of expression to use, that is the sort of punishment from which the United States could obtain some obtuse and bizarre satisfaction. If all the silos of the United States were knocked out in a first strike by the USSR, the United States nuclear submarines alone have a strike capacity equivalent to 21,000 Hiroshimas.

The British, of course, are following a similar pattern at the moment under their present government in relation to the Trident missile. The assumption again is that the present Trident missiles do not provide an adequate deterrent. The United States has decided to employ the cruise missile, the neutron bomb and to go ahead with the B1 bombers which will cost $100m apiece. I mention these things not to get involved in that sort of war games argument about who has the most weapons or who can in a multiplicity of times most destroy the other, but merely to illustrate how governments in a sense are mesmerised into making irrational decisions by the cry of rearmament. That is really the essential thing about this debate, whether we are to be mesmerised by ex-actors in the United States or by geriatrics in the Soviet Union-depending on our predeliction-into believing that this enormous strike capacity has any relevance to issues relating to the determination of international affairs and the future of humanity in any constructive way.

What can Australia do in this context? First, there is a need to have a clear and comprehensive policy on disarmament. Secondly, we should take every international opportunity to explain and advocate that policy. Thirdly, within Australia we should mobilise people and opinion to work for disarmament, particularly and urgently nuclear disarmament; and I do not mean unilateral disarmament. I do not think the Government has any clear or comprehensive policy on disarmament at all and it does not take every opportunity it can to advocate disarmament. One of the great failures of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting-CHOGM-in Melbourne was the failure to make a stronger statement on disarmament, and in that sense CHOGM was a lost opportunity.

There are more recent examples of the failure of disarmament policy. For example, I refer the Senate to President Reagan's words a few days ago which suggested that the United States had accepted the concept of a limited, winnable nuclear war in Europe. Immediately the story broke the Government of West Germany demanded a full explanation and rebuttal of the President's reported words. I mention this because it is necessary, if we are to talk seriously about this issue in the Senate, to face up to the fact that this is a matter of enormous concern on the continent of Europe. The aberrations, as some conservative spokesmen might like to call them, of what we have seen on television about nuclear disarmament concern in Europe are not going to go away under the present policies, because President Reagan not only scares the hell out of the Russians and out of me but he also scares the hell out of millions of people in Europe every time he makes pronouncements of the kind to which I have just referred. When Dr Helmut Schmidt, the Chancellor of West Germany, demanded an explanation of the President's words, Australia of course said nothing-the mouse that roared on this issue. We must not forget that if a nuclear war broke out, it would be a matter of concern to us in a strategic and very direct sense as well as a matter of concern in relation to the whole of the human race.

Fortunately that view of the President of the United States which brought such concern a week or two ago is not shared by the whole of the United States Congress. Senator Frank Church, the former Chairman of the United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said in Canberra on 21 October:
There is no such thing as limited nuclear war. Any nuclear exchange would quickly escalate out of control. Any talk of limited nuclear war is unreal.

What I am concerned about in this debate is that nobody should go away with the view that our allegiance to and friendship with the United States involve us in accepting some of the more bizarre propositions which stem from that country, because once the possibility, the notion, of winnable nuclear war has been sold we are a tremendous step down the road towards making nuclear war not only a possibility but also a probability. I think it is a matter of grave concern that not only this Parliament in discussing this issue but also the media in Australia have been prepared to give credence to some of those bizarre notions of limited nuclear war. It is good to think that some Americans in high places do not believe those things; it is terrifying to think that others do.

Another thing I would be concerned that Australia should do is to seek official or unofficial membership of the Independent Commission on Disarmament and Security Issues which is headed by Olaf Palme, a former Premier of Sweden. Membership of that Commission includes many distinguished persons from East and West and others from the Third World. We ought to be a member of that Commission. It is working to support and to publicise the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament. The recent American offer to make a formal proposal soon for a nuclear free zone in the Middle East, a constructive suggestion from the United States, is something which the Labor Party has welcomed and which the Government of Australia ought to be welcoming as an initiative. We ought to be committed to those sorts of policies in every field of potential world conflict. To the best of my knowledge that American proposal drew no support whatsoever from the Australian Government. To say the least, that was a major political and diplomatic omission.

I should point out that, while calling for disarmament, most of our major allies are supplying vast conventional armouries to smaller countries, yet very little is heard diplomatically from Australia on such arms agreements. The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute says that the Soviet Union supplies 30 per cent of arms sales to the Third World. The United States, not to be outdone, provides about 45 per cent of arms sales to the Third World. In the past 10 years arms sales to the Third World have totalled something like $US60 billion.

This country has a long and shameful history of overdependence on other powers in relation to defence and international matters. The Labor Party wants to see a more independent approach to those issues. We believe that not only would such an approach mean a safer Australia, but also it might, with some imagination and initiative on behalf of Australian governments, lead a little more to the possibility of a safer world. It is not just a question of the safety of Australia. Ultimately and more importantly, it is a question of Australia having the capacity, the imagination and the initiative to play a more independent and constructive role in ensuring world peace. If some of the suggestions which have been made during this debate were followed by the Government, we believe that that may be a practical possibility. If we are to continue this debate, do not let us do it on the basis of goodies and baddies but rather on the realities of world power and the possibility and prospect for peace in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance put by Senator Gietzelt in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The lack of concern by the Government regarding the effect of the accelerating global arms race.

The one point Senator Gietzelt made with which I can agree whole-heartedly is that the accelerating global arms race is a matter of critical importance. It is possibly the most critical of all matters that this Parliament could be debating. The only matter which is perhaps of greater importance is the reasons for the accelerating global arms race, the reasons why, regrettably, the United States of America in particular has been forced in recent times to accelerate its arms build-up. Those reasons were expressed in detail by our leader, Senator Carrick, in his speech.

The matter before the Senate refers to the Government's lack of concern. It is my submission that, if that is analysed, it will be found not to be so. In fact, in the whole of Senator Gietzelt's 20-minute speech he made only one point on that issue. He was critical of the Australian Government for it not being sufficiently critical of the United States. I submit to the Senate that an examination of the performance and the attitude of the Australian Government in relation to the arms build-up shows a real and meaningful concern and shows that Australia can play a role in this critical area. We all accept that Australia is not a major world power. We do not have the power to influence others by force, to take a certain course of action, but there are other ways in which we can make a worthwhile contribution. An analysis of the material shows that Australia is playing that role.

In this debate I particularly wish to refer to the report of the Australian delegation to the 1981 session of the Committee on Disarmament, which took place in Geneva between 3 February and 21 August this year. That report was brought down in this Parliament only last week. What is outstanding from that report is the real contribution that Australia can make in this critical area. I shall give some background on the Committee on Disarmament, for those who are unfamiliar with it. It arose out of the 1978 Special Session on disarmament of the United Nations General Assembly. The Committee consists of 40 member nations. Australia sought to be on it. It sought to make a contribution through that Committee and that, in itself, shows a concern for the critical work that can be performed by the Committee. It has met in the years since 1978 and has brought down annual reports. Reports have been submitted by the Government to the Parliament. As I indicated, the latest report was submitted only last week.

The work of the Committee is carried out under a number of heads. In the plenary session, it dealt with the two critical issues of the nuclear test ban treaty and nuclear disarmament. It has also broken up into four working groups which deal with four particular issues. The first issue is negative security assurances, which are assurances from the nations which have nuclear arms to the majority of nations which do not have them. A second working group deals with the frightening subject of chemical weapons. A third working group deals with the even more frightening subject of radiological weapons-a subject which is so frightening that the Committee has been unsuccessful in defining the potential of radiological weapons or even what they are. The fourth working group is considering a comprehensive program for disarmament. As I indicated, this Committee is a positive way in which a country of Australia's influence and size can make a worthwhile contribution to this debate. That is exactly what the work of this Committee has done over the years.

I refer the Senate to the opening speech made by Mr Walker, who headed our delegation on the Committee. The speech is included in the report brought down before the Parliament last week. Page 39 of the report states:
For Australia, two issues on our agenda are of outstanding importance; they are those concerning a comprehensive nuclear test-ban treaty and a chemical weapons convention.
He indicated that he wanted to say a few words on both subjects. With regard to the first subject, he said:

Australia's commitment to work for the prohibition of all nuclear test explosions in all environments for all time is well known and was once more made evident at the thirty-fifth session of the United Nations General Assembly. We see such a treaty as the most readily achievable measure that would offer effective and practical assurances to the international community against the dangers of continued testing, against the further growth of existing nuclear arsenals and against the extension of nuclear weapons to other countries. We place high value also on the contribution which such a treaty could make to reducing regional tensions in many parts of the world, and on its other many benefits. Australia believes that this is an appropriate, indeed an urgent, issue to be tackled by this Committee.
That was part of the address made by Mr Walker on behalf of this country to that international body.

Australia expressed concern that the tripartite working group on this subject had not been able to make the progress which we regard as desirable. Nevertheless, we are not prepared to let the matter rest at that stage. Although we expressed disappointment, we said that we could be doing other things in the meantime. We said that we might usefully start work on the international and administrative arrangements for an international network of seismic stations to verify compliance with a future test ban treaty. That is an example of Australia, in a situation in which the major world powers are having difficulty in reaching an agreement, taking a positive stand and putting an attitude that in the meantime we can do something worthwhile. The Senate might be interested to know that, in saying that, we were supported by Japan, Canada and a number of other countries although, regrettably, not by the majority. Nevertheless, we are playing a lead.

In a related activity, a group of seismic experts has been meeting under the auspices of the Committee for the last few years to examine some of the technical issues. We have made a contribution in that regard. The Australian representative on the seismic experts group, Mr Peter McGregor, was at the conference and continued to make a contribution. In fact, in one area we are leading the group's work, and that is the area to investigate the possibility of using the existing world-wide communications network of the World Meteorological Organisation to transmit messages containing seismic information such as would be needed for international verification of a comprehensive test ban treaty.

We confirmed again that we are prepared to play a critical role in relation to this most important issue. That is an example of Australia showing concern, not a lack of concern as is indicated in the wording of the proposal put forward for discussion by Senator Gietzelt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is taking the lead.

—Australia is taking the lead, as Senator Teague says. The other area in which I think we can argue that we are also taking the lead before this Committee on Disarmament is the working party on chemical weapons. If I may continue to refer to the speech by Mr Walker, as set out at page 40 of the report, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The other priority item is a chemical weapons convention. Here too, as with the test ban, the need for effective action is urgent. Delay, for whatever reason, carries awesome risks for the international community and for the inhabitants of our planet.

We know from the expert advice we have heard that many countries have the potential to manufacture chemical weapons. We know-press accounts abound-of reports of large arsenals of chemical weapons and the training of troops in their use. We know the pressures this causes for other countries to arm themselves in turn with even more fearsome new chemical weapons. The one hope of avoiding the chemical arms race which now threatens is to negotiate and put into place a chemical weapons convention. Such a convention must have reliable and convincing verification provisions if it is to provide the security which could remove the rationale for any country to arm itself with these weapons.

There again Australia is taking the lead. In the previous year, on Australia's initiative, the Committee on Disarmament set aside a few days for informal meetings with technical experts. Again that was done on our instigation. What is almost exciting from Australia's point of view, I think, is that delegations from other countries such as the Netherlands were coming to the Australian delegation and suggesting that the procedures we have previously set up should be continued at that last meeting.
Page 20 of the report details some of the work that we have done on the limitation of chemical weapons. The report states:

The Australian delegation was one of the most active delegations in all aspects of the Committee's work on Chemical Weapons. It contributed extensively to the Working Group's examination of the Chairman's draft elements.

That was an attempt to set up a draft convention. The Australian delegation produced working papers which were put to the Committee. We took a particular interest in the question of ensuring that the Committee would have access to expert advice. We provided our own experts. The Australian expert, Dr Freeman, participated in all of the meetings. The Australian delegation was also at pains to make arrangements for the chemicals weapons experts of different countries to get together outside the official Committee and working group meetings. Again Australia was taking in this awesome field of chemical weapons a lead in limiting chemical weapons for the benefit of all mankind. This was done by the Australian Government that the Opposition supporters in this discussion are attempting to criticise.

The action of the Australian delegation was not limited to only those fields. I refer honourable senators to the working party on radiological weapons. Honourable senators can see at page 26 of the report which was brought down last week that the working party and the Committee on Disarmament as a whole adopted a device, advocated by Australia in the previous year, to handle the Soviet wish for a full debate and the creation of a subsidiary body on the general topic of new weapons of mass destruction. The Soviet proposal was not accepted. Again, Australia took the lead. Instead of such elaborate and time consuming treatment, Australia instigated informal meetings at which experts from the Warsaw Pact countries were able to put forward their views. I put it to the Senate that that again is an example of Australia taking a lead, showing a major concern in this critical area.

In the Working Group on the Comprehensive Program of Disarmament, perhaps the most critical of all the working parties and undertaking the most critical of all the work being done by the Committee on Disarmament, again Australia is making a contribution to a world body set up by the United Nations to look particularly towards ways of arms limitation in the world, and at ways whereby the world can reach a situation of nuclear disarmament and stop nuclear tests. In this area Australia is making a major contribution. Under the heading 'Comprehensive Program of Disarmament' the report of the Australian delegation states:

The Australian delegation was active in support of these efforts, in particular in helping to draft two conceptual Western papers and in advancing wording for particular items in a draft Comprehensive Program of Disarmament . . .
In these areas I believe we can be proud of the contribution that Australia is making and of the attitude of our Government in ensuring that such a contribution is made.

Finally, I draw to the Senate's attention the fact that when it came to drawing up the final annual report of this international Committee, Australia was nominated by the Western Group to participate in the drafting of that final accord. If ever there was evidence in the international community that Australia's contribution in this most critical area is being recognised that must be it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance we are discussing concerns not the armaments race in the world generally but 'the lack of concern by our Government regarding the effect of the accelerating global arms race'. I think it is appropriate for us to consider the world background so that we can assess the scale within which we are working. It reveals that although Australia's spending on defence is considerable and increasing it is puny on the world scale. Of rather more importance are Australian attitudes towards both the military policies of other countries and, perhaps less obviously but of no less importance, the implications for the world of the mining and sale of Australian uranium. Perhaps the most impactive and memorable single background fact about global arms spending is that in 1980 world-wide military expenditure amounted to more than $1m for every minute of every day. Caspar Weinberger, the United States of America Secretary of Defense, has warned Americans that they may have to get used to the idea of spending 50 per cent of gross national product on weaponry for the armed forces. One-half of all research carried out in the world is on military projects. The World Health Organisation has estimated that the eradication of malaria from the world would cost less than one-thousandth of the world's annual military spending. The Brandt report on development states:

SPEECH.PARA: The cost of a ten-year program to provide for essential food and health needs in developing countries is less than half of one year's military spending.

When these facts are taken into account and the tragic implications that they have for the world really sink in it emerges as vitally important that individuals and nations of good will should do all that they can to encourage the reduction of this sort of spending even to some small extent. Even a fraction of a percentage taken off that rate of spending would, of course, be of enormous value elsewhere. Yet we find that on 19 February 1980 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), speaking on Afghanistan, stated:
As well as these immediate measures, and of greater importance, long-term policies to match Soviet power and staying-power must be formulated.
An indispensible element in that process must be the redressing of the trend in the military balance.

In this, as in other aspects, the main burden must fall on the United States. President Carter has already announced a series of measures which will strengthen the armed forces of the United States and, what is also very important, will increase their flexibility and their capacity to respond quickly to crises. But if the main burden falls on America, it is entitled to look for supporting measures in other countries that value their independence and the maintenance of world order. Other developed countries, including Australia, must respond. In this respect the recent decision to modernise and strengthen NATOs theatre nuclear weapons system is important.

Senator Carrick said earlier in this debate that the blame for the arms race falls equally on the Soviet Union. There is no doubt whatsoever about that. The issue of which of the zonal competitors contributes most to the problem is debated enormously in the world, but that is not a matter for debate now. One thing that is beyond doubt is that the Australian Government has more influence in Washington than it has in Moscow. I think this is highly relevant to the discussion we are having at present. I regret that I cannot recall in any of the defence statements made by the Government recently any policy initiatives aimed at influencing the United States away from military solutions. There have been a number of pious platitudes, but these have always been generalities and have never really come to specifics in any region where some constructive thinking might have been appropriate. Even those pious platitudes are thin on the ground. The general theme continues to be one of agreement that the only way to maintain peace is constant escalation of the weapons war. The Australian Democrats cannot accept that this is a rational or reasonable point of view; nor that it should be carried to the extent that the Government carries it.

The fact remains that even very small reductions in spending on armament could make the funds available for a profound improvement in the overall human condition. Perhaps the strangest irony of all is that while the wealth of the world is being spent to such a ludicrous extent on arms the conditions are encouraged which lead to the risk of more and more conflict. Poverty, deprivement and disease are hardships which do not, as the Victorian moralists say, improve the human character; far from it. They debase the human character. The hungry, deprived man is a desperate man. He can be persuaded to resort to arms only too easily. We have seen most terrible lessons of this kind in the last decade or two in both Asia and Africa. In virtually every case the armaments which destroyed and killed in those areas were provided by one or other of the zonal competitors of the world.

We cannot, as Senator Carrick has done, merely look at the question of armaments as being competition between two zones. There is a malicious, evil and thoroughly powerful and integrated force in the world which is there to provide arms to all who want them and to exploit misery, poverty and discord wherever they can be found. People for whom more might well have been done by the world and could easily be done by the world are merely being given a gun. We subscribe to policies which do not give the hungry man food but instead place a gun in his hand. All the major nations of the world subscribe to these policies and most of the middle powers of the world do not seem to worry very much about them. Everybody wrings his hands over the latest bloodbath in Africa or Asia but very few people stop to reason that that might not have happened at all had it not been for the escalation of the world arms industry.

As one of those who feel very badly about the predicament of the people of East Timor, I would like to look briefly at its relevance to this debate. It is, indeed, very relevant to this debate. The invasion and conquest of East Timor was a classic example of the naked use of armed force. There was no other justification for it. Indonesia has no historic, geographic, ethnic or cultural basis whatsoever for any claim to East Timor, and never has had. The matter was wholly based on the fact that Australia and Portugal-the colonising powers-were going through periods of political crisis and the opportunity was seen by the generals in Jakarta to grab East Timor. It was really as simple as that. Because of internal problems, Indonesia was looking for some sort of foreign adventure which would enable some form of what it would like to call discipline to be applied to the nation.

The fact is that Indonesia had and has the arms to conquer a small neighbouring country and to keep down its people by force of arms. As a result, perhaps one-third of the people of East Timor have died, and more will die yet. Indonesia is apparently intent on continuing the military solution there, even to the extent of a final act of genocide against the East Timorese people. Events in East Timor at this moment confirm that viewpoint, but the key point in the context of what we are now discussing is that Australia has approved of and accepted what is happening in East Timor. I have asked many questions here on this issue and each time I have been told that Australia regards East Timor as a part of Indonesia. East Timor is a part of Indonesia to the extent that she has been made that by the cynical and consistent use of armed force. Australia officially shows a lack of concern for the result of that use of armed force which is equally cynical and consistent. We set ourselves a dangerous precedent in this regard, I feel, and one which we might regret deeply in the not too distant future. It is not too late, I think, to mend our ways. Many thousands, possibly tens or hundreds of thousands, of Australians want the Government to tell Indonesia plainly that the continued military assault on the East Timorese people is an unacceptable use of force and that the end of military measures there and an act of self-determination would be in the best interests of all concerned, including the Indonesians themselves.

The next major lack of concern by the Australian Government towards the arms race in the world is shown in its apparent determination to mine and sell uranium in large quantities, knowing full well that, in spite of so-called safeguard agreements, a great deal of that uranium will inevitably end up in nuclear weapons. I think things that are going on in the world now make that fairly plain. Small nuclear weapons are being built in countries using so-called peaceful nuclear reactors. This proliferation, I think, will be one of the most worrying and troublesome problems that the world will face in the decades to come. It is a fact that so-called peaceful nuclear reactors-the power reactor, the thing which was going to provide power that was too cheap to be metered and which in other circumstances could well be a useful thing to the world but with which we have this terrible dilemma about its inevitable association in the future with the most appalling means that are in use in armed force-can be readily manipulated to produce weapons grade plutonium at a rate faster than that of a fast breeder reactor. The word 'fast' in that device, of course, refers only to the speed of the neutrons.

It is a fact also that many of the nations now interested in nuclear power reactors want them not to produce electricity but to provide the means by which to obtain for themselves a nuclear armoury. Those countries are, of course, such bastions of democracy-I speak sardonically-as Libya, South Korea, Argentina and Pakistan, countries notorious for their irrationality and autocracy and, in some cases, their apparent willingness to cause trouble outside their own borders. Much of the spread of nuclear power through the world is now to nations such as those, several of which are already known to be in the process of making nuclear weapons with the product of those reactors. There is no doubt at all that this is happening in the world and will continue in the future at an accelerated rate. What kind of nuclear weapons will they make? It will not be the balance of terror, fusion weapon-the hydrogen bomb. None of those countries have the sophisticated technology to make those things. Instead, they are wishing on the world in large quantities, and in even larger quantities in the future, the small, dirty fission-type weapon which was used at Hiroshima and Nagasaki-the atom bomb, the crude primitive atom bomb with its high rate of fall-out and its contamination of the atmosphere in ways which last for tens of thousands of years.

I will briefly sketch an unpleasant scenario for the future which the proliferation of these weapons, inevitably associated with the spread of nuclear power, is likely to produce. We can see a process of gradualism in which decade after decade more and more of these weapons are used in regional wars. The word is getting around the world especially now that it is possible to have a limited nuclear war. The major zones of the world are encouraging this viewpoint. We will inevitably, I suggest, see a world in which these armouries of fission weapons are used. We will see the results perhaps only on our television sets but inevitably the deadly cloud of fall-out will increase. The radioactivity each time one of those weapons is exploded will affect every person on this globe. We see a hideous world in which the rates of deformity and cancer become so high that eventually through this process of gradualism every family on the planet will be affected by those weapons in one way or another. This is not a nightmare dream of the future but a reasoned and only too likely result of the continued development of nuclear power. We have shown in the world already that we cannot control the proliferation of plutonium, that we cannot prevent its being used for nuclear weapons, regardless of any safeguard agreements or anything of the kind. If Australia continues to export uranium and to encourage the world to this lemming-like rush to the precipice I think we will regret it within our own lifetime.

The statement is made that if we do not do it others will, but let me give an analogy. There is in Australia plenty of good hilltop country on which we could grow opium in large quantity. We could use the same logic-if we do not supply it somebody else will. I submit, Mr Acting Deputy President, that such logic is not good enough in any honest country.

Finally, I would like to make a few points concerning the Government's defence policy, such as it is, particularly that which concerns the aircraft carrier which the Government seems so bent on purchasing at higher cost and which the Australian Democrats for the past two years have opposed over and over again. I am glad to see that the Australian Labor Party now also opposes that ridiculous purchase and takes the view that we should not have weapons such as an aircraft carrier, which apparently is designed mainly for foreign adventurism and flag flying. If all nations possessed only those arms reasonably necessary for their defence most of the problems created by the world arms race would disappear. Australia can provide an important example in this regard. In so doing we would also be providing rationally for our independence, for our ability to defend this country in all circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take part in this important discussion this afternoon on what has been described as the lack of concern by the Government regarding the effect of the accelerating global arms race. Of course, I certainly do not agree that there is any lack of concern on the part of the Government about an accelerating global arms race. Nor do I believe that any Australian of any political view would take the stance that there was nothing to be worried about in such a circumstance. What we have to do responsibly this afternoon is identify whether the sort of arms race that exists in some measure today is in the ultimate the greatest determinant in finally establishing a sensible and peaceful approach to the problems that confront this world.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall that earlier in this discussion Senator Button referred to military preparedness as being necessary to ensure ultimate disarmament. He alleged that there was a measure of confusion in people's minds between military preparedness and disarmament. I want to make the point-it occurs to me as being of some significance at least-that the history of mankind over many centuries, including indeed in the twentieth century, has been a permanent illustration of the fact that military unpreparedness is certainly a determinant of war. If one looks at the situation in Europe in the period prior to 1914 one finds that a massive European power was able basically to bring about one of the most tragic and destructive wars in mankind's history largely because there was no preparedness, either mental or physical, on the part of others to withstand it. Regrettably, less than a generation later, in 1939, once again a massive power-physically, mentally and philosophically as well as from the point of view of military capacity-rose and roamed across Europe. At that stage again the rest of the world was totally unprepared, physically and mentally, to withstand that serious threat.

What was the result? As I recall the years 1939 to 1945 they represented one of the most tragic eras in the history of mankind, an era marked by the greatest destruction and physical deprivation that man had ever known. I suggest that one of the significant contributing causes-although not, of course, the only one-of that disaster and of the previous disaster in the first 50 years of this century was the unpreparedness, mental and physical, of the rest of the world to withstand a massive force. Consequently I do not believe it is illogical to assume that one of the determinants of peace in the future will be our determination to maintain a force, a capacity to defend ourselves, which is in every sense relevant to the sort of force that may conceivably oppose us. I make the point that military unpreparedness is almost a guarantee of military disaster, even though ironically throughout history very often those who were unprepared in the beginning may ultimately, for all sorts of reasons that have been suggested, run out as, in a sense, the victors-if indeed there are any victors in these massive conflicts.

Since 1945 there have been wars-relatively minor wars-but there has been a period of relative peace. In that period there has been a determination, I believe, by the major powers to keep within cooee of each other from a point of view of military capacity. I am not suggesting that this is not a sad situation. Of course it is a sad situation, but if it creates a circumstance whereby we have a capacity to move on in relative peace, to discuss and examine the problems-political, social and economic-that confront the human race, then it serves a very real purpose indeed. I believe it is impossible for any sensible person to allege that there is a lack of concern in this Government-I hope the same applies to the mind of any Australian-about the accelerating global arms race. Of course there is a concern. We must determine that it shall not resolve itself into international conflict, but at the same time we have to realise that on the evidence of history there is more chance that we will survive by having a power at our command which is comparable to any power that is likely to oppose us. Indeed, to suggest a lack of concern in this Australian Government or in any Australian Government infers a total lack of appreciation of the history of this country.

In the first 40-odd years of this century we suffered World Wars I and II to which I have already referred. They were events of massive suffering. We suffered problems in conflicts in Korea, Malaysia and Vietnam. We have taken part in peacekeeping forces in many places around the world-in Korea, Cyprus, the Sinai and so on. The concern of this Government for peace is a genuine concern and this Government seeks continually to find a resolution. The history of this Government's attempts to find that resolution have been very clearly outlined by Senator Hill, who spoke previous to me. He defined specifically the areas involved and the attitudes that Australia has taken in a continuing and increasing search for international control of armaments-in particular nuclear armaments-and chemical warfare. Our involvement in wars-regrettably, we have had a number of such involvements-has never been to seek sovereign power or territorial gain. Our involvement in war, I believe, genuinely has been an involvement that has sought to establish and maintain a measure of freedom for human beings wherever they may be. That is an important matter to keep at the back of one's mind when looking at Australia's involvement in the control of warfare problems in the current period and in the future. We in this country are and have been, and I would say will remain in the foreseeable future, a trading nation of great significance. The whole of our economy, the whole of our social and economic structure, is based on our capacity to succeed around the world as a trading nation. Indeed, we have been and are successful, and our capacity to remain that way is largely determined by our capacity to contribute to the peaceful solution of problems around the world.

Yet another reason why this country and this Government are significantly determined that, within their power, they should contribute to the maximum to peace around the world is surely the nature of our resources. We are producers of food, of fibre and of energy resources which are needed around the world by developed and developing countries. We have an obligation not only to establish those resources, to develop them and to make them available to the world that needs them, but also to play our part in seeking to maintain and establish a peaceful circumstance in which those sorts of commitments can be made. I suppose it is an irony, but it is a fact, that in order to secure a real measure of peace one has to be prepared. This has been a painful lesson of history and I have referred to a number of cases during my remarks this afternoon. As I observe it, there is no realistic alternative. Regrettably, when the forces around the world that oppose each other on all sorts of grounds-social, philosophical and economic-recognise that none of them can win, that they are equally strong, then and perhaps then only will we have realistic, proper and constructive discussions to solve the sorts of problems that are relevant to all people everywhere. If we are to ensure that this world continues to develop not by revolutionary but by evolutionary processes and to have within it a measure of permanency, then, perhaps regrettably but nevertheless certainly, we have to establish the sort of power that will make our side of the fence a deterrent to those who seek to establish a sovereignty and a territorial right over other peoples, wherever they may be.

Having said all that, let me just for a moment refer to the sorts of efforts that Australia seeks to make traditionally in the field of international disarmament. Throughout the existence of the United Nations, the Government has sought to establish through that body, in which the Government has taken a leading role, the control of nuclear arms, chemical warfare and the like. Madam Acting Deputy President, as my time to speak has run out, I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I present the one hundred and ninety-second report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Committee's one hundred and ninety-second report on statistics takes, as its starting point, the 1974 report on the Integration of Data Systems known as the Crisp report. That inquiry identified three major deficiencies in data systems: Poor co-ordination of statistical collections; inadequate communication between producers and users of statistics; and poor accessibility to data that was collected. Unfortunately many of these problems remain in 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the Crisp report the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act 1975 was passed to establish the Australian Bureau of Statistics as a statutory authority charged with co-ordinating statistical systems in Australia. However, the Act appears to have failed in its central purpose because the Bureau's powers are not sufficient. A suggestion made by the Committee in this report is that the Bureau's powers be clarified and strengthened.

There is a widely held view abroad in the business community that collections of basic economic data are, in some areas, wholly inadequate. In this regard I refer honourable senators to an article in the Australian of 19 October 1981 where a Sydney stockbroking firm, Dominguez and Barry, had to research such sources as Reserve Bank bulletins, Budget Papers, as well as ABS figures to determine the average per capita public debt, as the Government publishes no such figures. The article quotes these brokers as calling upon the Government for better statistical information on State and Federal borrowings and that currently information in this area is very poor.

This paper addresses, in part, this problem. It also discusses the advantages of allowing the Bureau access to identified taxation data on businesses as a way of reducing the respondent burden for statistical collections. Access to taxation data, particularly businesses, was recommended in the 1974 Crisp report. Both the Bureau and the Australian Taxation Office sent representatives to assess the systems of tax access for economic statistics operating in Canada and the United States of America in 1979. Surprisingly, no results of the joint investigations by the Bureau and the Taxation Office have yet been presented to the Treasurer (Mr Howard).The proposed access to tax data is supported by the Australian Law Reform Commission, the Australian Taxpayers Association and the Confederation of Australian Industry. It is to be hoped that this discussion paper will stimulate debate on this sensitive issue.

Also, on the question of accessibility to data, it is pleasing to note the Bill introduced on 15 October 1981 by the Treasurer to amend the Census and Statistics Act to allow census data, with personal identifiers removed, is to be made more widely available. The Crisp inquiry in 1974 had recommended even wider changes to this Act. These recommendations were endorsed by the Crawford report on structural adjustment. The Law Reform Commission also recommended certain liberalisations in 1979 and some of these have been accepted by the Government.

The Committee is still concerned that accessibility to data collection is not optimal, and that savings can be made by reducing duplication of collections and making more useful data more widely available. Of course, increased accessibility carries with it the danger of infringement of privacy. The Committee is very conscious of this danger but feels guidelines put forward in a recent Law Reform Commission discussion paper, entitled, 'Privacy and Personal Information', will provide adequate protection in this regard.

I refer to one other issue raised in the report; that of the paper burden imposed on business by government. This was the subject of a recent interdepartmental inquiry but the outcome of that study disappoints the Committee. We feel that more can be done in this area and suggest that initiatives recently taken overseas, particularly in Canada and the USA, deserve serious consideration in Australia. The Committee believes that one initiative that would have a positive effect would be a central register of all statistical collections and for the Bureau to be given suitable powers to authorise and advise on the form of statistical collections by other government instrumentalities. The Committee hopes that the issues raised in this report, and the suggestions made, will encourage a wide-ranging discussion on matters that impact very heavily on Australia's overall economic performance. I commend the report to honourable senators.

I wish to make a few personal remarks about the report and the three deficiencies which the Committee found to be the most glaring and the most important to be acted upon-the poor co-ordination of statistical collections, the inadequate communications between producers and users of statistics and poor accessibility to data that was collected. An Act was passed in 1975 to establish the Australian Bureau of Statistics as a statutory authority charged with co-ordinating statistical systems in Australia; unfortunately that has not happened. As was stated on page 13 of the report, the Act places obligation for such collection on the Bureau rather than on departments. Unfortunately, the Bureau has not taken the necessary action to clarify its powers and the Committee found that completely unsatisfactory.

The ABS attitude to the whole process of collecting statistical data is very stubborn; the Bureau believes that it has the answers to all the questions. The data collected by the Bureau is not as complete or as reliable as it ought to be. Small businesses which have to supply innumerable statistical data to the Government or to government departments consider that collection an imposition which is very costly to them. I believe that the ABS should do something about it. It should compile a register of all statistical data collected by various bodies in this country and make it available to all those bodies which would like the information but would not know where to find it and might therefore start a collection of data which might be a duplication of data already somewhere in the files but which nobody knows about. I hope that the report, which is a discussion paper, will lead to some positive action by the ABS to improve the collection and dissemination of data in Australia.

After all, the Public Accounts Committee is a joint committee made up of senators and members and Senator Georges is the Deputy Chairman of the Committee. SPEECH.PARA: Members of the House of Representatives and the Senate carry out a lot of important work as members of Committees. They put in long hours of work. I believe that the reports of committees are of a high standard and have long term implications for the society which we serve. Therefore, I am concerned that far too little time is given to debating important reports made by Senate committees. I would certainly like the situation changed to ensure that the reports of joint committees are tabled in both Houses on the same day. I am concerned because reports such as the ones we have before us are far-reaching.

Statistics are important to government and the cost of preparing information for government is very high. Certain businesses are rather sceptical about the number of collections in which they are asked to participate. The recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee in this respect are not without some controversy, but I believe that they represent a marked improvement on the existing situation. I believe that we must look to upgrading the status of the Australian Bureau of Statistics because at the moment it is very much under the thumb and direction of the Treasury. I believe not only that it must be given a greater co-ordinating role but also that it must be given a greater degree of independence.

I believe that the Commonwealth Government financial administration handbook will make a major contribution to the understanding by the electorate of what goes on in this place, how money is appropriated and how it is spent. I therefore welcome its presentation and I hope that it will be given wide distribution. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, I present the reports relating to the following proposed works:

SPEECH.PARA: Construction of working, living and area facilities for Army and Navy personnel at Watsonia, Victoria and upgrading of airport facilities for the introduction of domestic wide-body aircraft.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief statement relating to the reports.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Public Works Committee's report on the upgrading of airport facilities at a number of airports for the introduction of wide-bodied aircraft is the first report on this reference. It makes recommendations on works at Coolangatta, Sydney, Melbourne and Perth. A second report will be presented early next year in respect of work at Adelaide and Hobart. In the limited time available to the Committee since the reference of this work on 27 August 1981, the Committee has not been able to schedule a hearing in Adelaide, from where a substantial number of submissions have been received from local organisations and the public. A public hearing will be set down for December. In order to avoid any substantial delay in completing the work at Adelaide, the Department of Housing and Construction will be proceeding with detailed planning of the Adelaide work. The Committee has been unable also to complete its examination of the proposed works at Hobart. These works also will be included in the second report.

The Committee is concerned at the number of works being referred to it which are deemed urgent. For instance, the works at Watsonia for the Department of Defence which are reported on today are required to be completed by the end of 1982. This arises from the transfer, in late 1982, of the Army Apprentice School, to which the Army School of Music is administratively attached, from Balcombe to Bonegilla. This move has been planned for some years so that the consequential requirement for accommodation and facilities for the Army School of Music has been known for quite some time. Other recent references to the Committee have also had a similar degree of urgency-for instance, the references on facilities for wide-bodied aircraft, for further dredging work at Brisbane Airport and for the upgrading of the international terminal building at Brisbane Airport.

The Committee is required by the Public Works Committee Act to report to the Parliament as expeditiously as possible. This it does. The average time between reference of a work to the Committee and presentation of the Committee's report is some three months. Three of the reports presented today and during the last sitting week were, in fact, completed in two months from the date of referral by the Senate. When it is taken into account that the Committee allows at least one month on each reference for the receipt of public submissions, the Senate will readily understand the pressures put on the Committee when a number of works deemed urgent are referred to it. The Committee attempts to fit in with the Government's works program. It does all that it can to avoid delays to works. The Committee is not, however, prepared to compromise its scrutiny of referred works. It is felt that if the Government can reduce the number of references involving urgent works by better planning or by earlier reference to the Committee, the scrutiny of public works expenditure entrusted by the Parliament to the Public Works Committee will be facilitated.

In its report on the upgrading of airport facilities for the introduction of wide-bodied aircraft, the Committee is critical that a number of the works at airports had been commenced in 1980-81 without reference to the Committee. These works totalled some $6.08m although no single work at any airport was in excess of $2m, the cost requiring reference to the Public Works Committee. However, certain of these works have pre-empted effective committee examination. The situation at Perth Airport, for instance, clearly demonstrates this point. During 1980-81, works totalling $1.9m were commenced involving both a departure lounge, and an arrivals lounge and baggage handling area. Part of the proposed works for Perth Airport now being reported on involve extensions or adaptions to these earlier works commenced last year. In effect, the domestic terminal development has been decided and commenced without scrutiny by the Public Works Committee or without the opportunity for comment by the public, by local government or by other interested groups. In fact, I feel that had the Public Works Committee considered the works, the current situation in the new arrivals area, where there are no toilet facilities, may well have been avoided.

The Committee understands that the works were required urgently to facilitate the introduction of wide-body aircraft by Trans Australia Airlines. But it cannot accept that proper investigation by the Committee would have unduly delayed the works. The Committee is heartened by the following comments of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) in his second reading speech on the Public Works Committee Amendment Bill 1981:

It is understood that the Committee was particularly concerned with cases where major works costing over $2m have been phased in over several years with small projects-below $2m. These projects have either escaped committee scrutiny, or if referred to the Committee, have been referred at a stage where proper committee investigation has been pre-empted by the work already done. The Government expects work totalling over $2m to be subject to parliamentary scrutiny, and will do all it can to ensure that all works required to be examined by the Committee in accordance with the Public Works Committee Act will be so examined. I have assured the Committee that should it wish to examine any work below $2m the Government would treat any request sympathetically, and would facilitate committee investigation of any such work.

Finally, I thank all members of the Committee for their industry and dedication during this year. This year has been a very busy one for the Committee and the work load on members has been heavy. All members have responded and worked well. I thank them for their help. In particular I thank the two vice-chairmen throughout the year; Senator Melzer in the first part of the year and, since July, the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Les McMahon). Similarly, I extend the thanks of all Committee members to the staff of the Public Works Committee. They have been of great value to the Committee and the Committee's work has been possible only because of their loyalty and dedication.
