SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to China and Japan and seek leave to make a fairly brief statement relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was honoured to have the opportunity of leading the Australian Parliamentary Delegation which visited Hong Kong, China and Japan from 30 June to 18 July of this year. We considered that the purpose of our visit was to express the interest and goodwill of the Australian Parliament and people towards China and Japan and to gather there information about the political, social and economic conditions that exist in those countries in order to be able to report to this Parliament. I consider that the Delegation was extremely beneficial in providing an exchange of views and in improving relations with those two countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Our primary concern was to strengthen the relationships that have developed with China and Japan and to find out what difficulties and problems now exist in our relations with those countries. The program enabled us to meet with government officials and representatives of industry, commerce and the professions. The role of Australia in the Pacific area is welcomed by China and Japan and the development of an independent future role is being watched with special interest. The success of the Delegation's visit to China was primarily due to the generous and hospitable manner in which the Delegation was received by the Chinese Government. It should be noted that this was only the second Parliamentary Delegation to visit China. The first Delegation visited China eight years ago. I would like to draw the particular attention of the Senate to one of the recommendations of our Delegation. That was that in future Australian delegations should be sent to China on a regular basis-say every three years-and that future delegations visit China only rather than two or three different countries.

On behalf of the Delegation I wish to express our gratitude to the Australian Commission in Hong Kong and the Australian Embassies in Beijing and Tokyo for the assistance they provided throughout our visit. I would also like to pay tribute to the fine spirit of co-operation shown by all members of the Delegation. The members were: Senator Ron Elstob, who is here tonight and who will probably want to say something after me; the Honourable Bill Morrison, who was deputy leader; the Honourable Evan Adermann; Mr Ted Innes; and Mr Grant Chapman. I think I can say that we functioned well as a team and effectively represented Australia in the two countries we visited.

I would like to add a few brief remarks of my own about what we saw in China in particular. In Japan we were treading a well trodden path. In China we were in a country which not many know much about and in which we, I am sure, saw some things we had not recognised were there before we went there. I would like to say something first about the economic situation in China. China admits that it has an inflation rate of 5 per cent. Some people suggest it might be as high as 20 per cent. It also has a significant youth unemployment problem. Nevertheless, the Chinese people in the streets certainly look well clothed and adequately fed. What the Chinese have clearly succeeded in doing is distributing a very low per capita national income equitably. In fact, the distribution of income is as equitable as we have managed to achieve in this country. I think we all know that we have one of the most equitable distributions of income in the world. For instance, as an example of the equitableness of China's income distribution, in China a factory worker gets about half as much as a factory manager in take-home pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not happen here.

—The after tax situation in Australia is very close. A manager gets about twice as much as a shop floor worker after tax. Admittedly, in China the fringe benefits are relatively more valuable. The manager of a factory in China gets a car. That is also the case in Australia, but of course in China everyone else has a bicycle. In Australia everyone else has a car. The equity of income distribution in China is as good as it is in Australia and I think we should recognise that.
—In China the managers are better off than they are in Australia.

—I was making the point that it is relative because of the fringe benefits. A manager earns about double the earnings of a factory worker. The distribution of income after tax is about the same as that in Australia. People could argue whether it is the same or worse. Nevertheless, we should not have the impression that income distribution in China is absolutely flat. It is about the same as in Australia and I think the Chinese deserve credit for that. Their real problem is that their productivity is deplorable. A shop floor worker in a factory gets about $40 a month. A bicycle-all bicycles in China are black, by the way-costs $160. It take four months for a factory worker to buy a bicycle. In Australia it takes a few days. In China, because of productivity, it takes three to four months and that is the dominant problem of the Chinese. If they want to solve their difficulties they have to find some way in which they can create incentives to work harder or more efficiently. The Government of China is well aware of this problem and is doing what it can to solve it. I doubt whether the Chinese can solve it within the present structure. They may do so. It is the real problem which they are trying to tackle, but they have structural problems in overcoming it. It may well be fortunate that their productivity is so low. If China, with one billion people, could match what has been achieved in productivity by Chinese communities elsewhere in Asia-in Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore-it would economically dominate the world. This is the central problem: how to raise its productivity to a reasonable level.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point on which I wish to make a personal remark concerns foreign affairs. We had very frank discussions with senior Chinese officials on the Soviet Union, Vietnam, Kampuchea, Taiwan and Hong Kong. I think there is a danger of euphoria in some quarters in Australia that there is a miraculous coincidence of views between our foreign policy and that of China. It is true that our views on the Soviet Union and Vietnam in some areas are the same. Nevertheless, we must recognise that although our trade with China will certainly grow, China has a very long term view of history. Its foreign policy is, quite properly, devoted to the interests of China. Its interests will by no means always be the same as ours. We must recognise that. We must not be carried away by euphoria because of an apparent coincidence in our attitudes and China's attitudes in particular areas. Our foreign policy and China's foreign policy will not always be the same. Its interests and ours are different. Its interests are China; ours are necessarily Australia. Despite those remarks, the trip to China was one of enormous fascination for me. The Chinese people are a charming, wonderful and hospitable people. It was a great privilege to lead a delegation to their country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I visited China in 1975 and again this year with the Australian delegation. A great deal of change had occurred between 1975 and this year. In October 1975 I saw the end of the Cultural Revolution, which I believe set China back some 50 years. Now that China has resolved its earlier problems I believe it will get around to solving the many difficulties that beset it. As we learned, not only can China capably feed her own people, she can also house and clothe them. For a nation with 1,000 million people, that is a gigantic job. What impresses me is the way the Chinese behave towards each other. Their behaviour is a delight for any Australian to see. Each Chinese, I believe, feels and thinks that he is his brother's keeper, and I think that has been the salvation of China. This long tradition of the family has helped China through all her difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Hamer said, China has difficulties in the manufacturing industries, but it excels in handicraft. The Chinese produce the finest embroidery and handwork in the world, and it is in this area that they should look seriously at exporting. Later, when more knowledge is gained and more technology is introduced, undoubtedly China will improve its performance in the manufacturing industries. I agree with Senator Hamer that at present China's performance in this area is very poor.

The members of the Australian delegation visited many areas, and the one in which I was interested was Shanghai, the shipping area. I feel that China will have to improve her ship-handling methods if she is to improve her export trade. The goods China exports throughout the world will have to arrive on time, and most certainly China will have to look to improving the handling of ships in the major ports. China's containerisation methods are not up to world standard, and perhaps Australia could give the Chinese some valuable advice in this area. I agree with Senator Hamer that it is imperative for Australian politicians to visit China regularly. We also should issue invitations to the National Chinese People's Congress for its members to come regularly to Australia. Australians get on very well with the Chinese, and it is important to create dialogue with them, not only in trade but also in foreign affairs. Although Australia is not a major military power our credibility in the Asian area is very good and I believe Australia should exercise some influence in this area and try to reduce tension. I think that the more Australian politicians go regularly to China the better for all concerned.

It was a great delight for me to visit China once again. I found the Chinese most friendly. They welcomed the delegation and could not do enough for us. Certainly there were things with which we all disagreed. The Chinese thought that the Pol Pot regime was not too bad. Undoubtedly, we in this country think that the Pol Pot regime is probably the worst regime in the history of the world. Nevertheless, we had a great deal to talk about and a lot of ideas to exchange. China needs to import and export. As I said, it is important for Australian politicians to go to China regularly, to make contact with the Chinese Government and to improve our relationship. I ask the Government to consider this matter seriously. It would be in the best interests of all countries if we improved our relationship. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the motion which has been moved by Senator Missen for the postponement of intervening business until after the consideration of an item of General Business which he has described as being urgent and important. The motion arises from a matter which was put before the Senate by a report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in November 1978. Pursuant to the procedures which were initiated by this Government, which require a formal response to parliamentary committee reports, there was a formal response to the Committee's recommendations on 22 November 1979, and that, of course, was almost two years ago. So, this proposition has been before the Senate since November 1978. As the Government's decision not to support the proposition has been known to the Senate since November 1979, it is a little difficult to see how the matter can be described as urgent and important in the sense that it should take precedence over the consideration of the business of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: There is, of course, a practice in the Senate whereby private members' business is normally dealt with on Thursday evenings. That is a practice which is not always honoured in this Senate. It is true that towards the end of a session it is not uncommon for the Thursday night to be taken up by Government Business. The most appropriate time, I suggest, for the matter to be before the Senate is the time which is normally reserved for private members' business. It is a little hard to see, when one looks at the importance of the legislation over which the honourable senator is seeking precedence-I refer to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981, the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981 and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1981, as well as the other items which are listed-and at the hour of the day, that this is a matter of such urgency that it ought to be given priority over that business. For those reasons the Government suggests to the Senate that it would not be appropriate for intervening business to be postponed. If the Senate is minded to deal with this particular motion, among all the items of General Business which are before it, then the appropriate thing would be for time to be reserved on Thursday evening under General Business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to indicate the attitude of the Opposition to this matter. It is not entirely new. Senator Missen has been seeking for several weeks to have this matter brought on in one form or another, and the form is now slightly changed, I gather, in view of an amendment which is likely to be moved. We have given an undertaking to Senator Missen that we think it a matter of sufficient importance to be brought on at this stage, and we will vote accordingly if we are called upon so to vote. I am not entirely persuaded by the view of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) that as this matter has been around since 1978 and as it is two years since the Government's response it should in fact be put in limbo for ever more.
—I suggested Thursday night.

—I know Senator Chaney charitably suggested Thursday night. The Government has been making an awful lot of suggestions about what business should be conducted on Thursday nights and in what order it should be conducted. We are not disposed to accede to the Government's suggestions about the way the Opposition or non-Government senators should conduct their business. It does not matter whether this relates to the order in which business is conducted or the circumstances of the agenda for any particular night of non-Government business. As I say, I merely indicate the Opposition's attitude on that matter. We hope that Senator Missen, as he has indicated to us, will be able to dispose of the matter very quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which brought down the report in favour of this chamber assuming a role in the scrutiny of Bills and proposed laws being dealt with by the Parliament I rise briefly to support Senator Missen. I believe that here we have an essential strengthening of the role of the Senate. Honourable senators will know that the Australian Labor Party is committed to the Senate as a House of review, a properly limited role as a House of review, one that does not extend to the bringing down of the Government which retains the confidence of the House of Representatives. I believe that we would be doing ourselves a disservice in this chamber and doing the whole Parliament a disservice if we postponed once again an opportunity to strengthen that review function, a function which merely alerts the chamber to the possibility that proposed laws may, indeed, offend civil liberties, confer undue discretions on administrators and such matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the time that has elapsed since the tabling of the report, a matter alluded to by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), is in fact already to our shame. Certainly, the response by the Government 12 months-a procrastinating, dilatory 12 months-after the tabling of the report, was totally inadequate, totally negative and conceded none of the points made by the Committee. It is perhaps somewhat to our shame that 24 months have elapsed since that government response. The matter is not before the chamber. I believe that to postpone the deliberation further will weaken rather than strengthen the proper role of this chamber. For that reason I strongly support Senator Missen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was impressed with what the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) had to say. I can understand the reasons why the Government would want to continue its program. On the other hand, I have sympathy with Senator Missen's wish and the Opposition's wish to have a matter of such importance debated. Another honourable senator has paid me the courtesy of informing me of an amendment he proposes to move to Senator Missen's motion. This is totally acceptable to the Australian Democrats. I ask whether this matter would be resolved easily if Senator Chaney gave an undertaking to Senator Missen and the Senate that this matter would be debated on Thursday night.
—No, thank you. It is not for him to do it. It is our night; it is not the Government's night.

—I have not been persuaded-I do not know about my colleagues-that there is sufficient urgency to debate this matter on Tuesday night rather than on Thursday night of this week. An important legislative program of the Government is to be undertaken. There are important Bills to be dealt with. If we could be briefed more on how long Senator Missen will take and how long the senator who proposes to move the amendment will take and on the attitude of the political parties in this place, and if the thing could be dispatched with expedition, we might well take another position. But if we want to vote for the motion with the Opposition, we are being asked virtually to sign a blank cheque and commit ourselves to a debate that might last all night. Senator Evans in good faith shakes his head to indicate that that is not so. I know that on this sort of subject in the Senate everyone becomes an expert. Before we know where we are everybody in the Senate is away in the debate, 10.30 p.m. comes and we are not one inch further down the track. I can sympathise with the Government's view. If we can get some undertaking my strong view on this occasion would be to support the Government provided justice is done to Senator Missen and he is allowed to bring this matter up at a time appropriate and suitable to the Senate.

—in reply-I understand that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) is prepared to give an undertaking that he will support the bringing on of this matter on Thursday evening, I assume at 8 o'clock.
—That isn't the Government's program.

—I am prepared to accept Senator Chaney's undertaking that the debate will, therefore, be brought on on Thursday evening if the Senate agrees with that. Senator Chipp raised that question. I think I am prepared to accept that the Government will not oppose its being brought on on Thursday evening. That being so, I see no harm in the later day being chosen. I suppose that if the parties-I do not refer to the Australian Democrats-are to make appointments to the committee they cannot really do that until next week when the House of Representatives meets again. Therefore, I would be prepared to accept that assurance. I do not know whether I should move that the debate on the motion be adjourned to Thursday evening.
—The motion can be put and if it is negated by the Senate it will amount to the same thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Perhaps I should explain the position of the Opposition in relation to the suggestion before us, which has arisen, I suppose, from the state of bliss in which Senator Chipp has been in the last few weeks concerning what has been happening in this place. Might I explain that the Government has already negotiated with us about the desirability of debating the Appropriation Bills, which represent Government Business, on Thursday night. I repeat, that has already been the subject of discussion. We were prepared to accede to Senator Missen's proposal tonight but the Government said: 'No, we will take Senator Missen's proposal on Thursday night'.
—It will be dealt with as well-not instead of.

—I understand that. If the honourable senator is negotiating on behalf of the Government it is the first role in which she has been cast where she might be as good as anybody else. We would like to see a consistent position adopted in relation to these matters. I indicate our attitude because it was in the light of those considerations, among others, that we agreed to support Senator Missen.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I say that I understand the negating of my motion to be subject to the Government being prepared to support my bringing it on at 8 p.m. on Thursday evening, and that I am working on that basis.

This Bill combines two measures relating to health expenditure. First, it provides for an amendment of the National Health Act 1953 to increase the general patient contribution for pharmaceutical benefits. This was announced by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech. The other matter I foreshadowed as Acting Minister for Health in the Senate on 16 September relates to the supply of pharmaceuticals in public hospitals under the new health funding arrangements. Honourable senators will be aware that these arrangements came into operation on 1 September this year.

In relation to the increase in the general patient contribution for pharmaceutical benefits I draw honourable senators' attention to clause 3 of the Bill. That clause will increase from $2.75 to $3.20 the maximum amount that approved pharmaceutical chemists may charge for the supply of a pharmaceutical benefit under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. This increase will take effect from 1 December 1981.
As in the past, pensioners holding a pensioner health benefits card and their dependants will not be charged for pharmaceutical benefits.
Similarly no charge will be made for sickness beneficiaries holding a health benefits card, and their dependants.
It is now over two years since the patient contribution was set at $2.75 and this increase of 45 cents is broadly in line with movements in prices and incomes since then.

I now turn to the supply of pharmaceuticals in public hospitals. Under the new health funding arrangements, annual grants are paid to each State pursuant to the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981 for the provision of health services by the States.

The grants include an amount towards the cost to the hospitals of supplying pharmaceuticals to all patients. The amount is related to the expenditure by States for pharmaceuticals under the previous hospital cost sharing agreements which in most States expired on 30 June this year. To synchronise with the new health insurance arrangements the agreements continued without formal agreements until 31 August.
The States are being funded for pharmaceuticals under the new arrangements to the extent that can be justified by past experience.

Within the National Health Act there is an alternative provision whereby hospital authorities could be reimbursed for their expenditure on pharmaceutical benefits. Section 94 authorises the approval of hospital authorities to supply pharmaceutical benefits and those authorities are entitled to a reimbursement at a level determined by the Minister under section 99.
This arrangement operated until the commencement of the Commonwealth/State cost sharing agreements in 1975. Under those agreements States had agreed not to claim under section 99.

In States where those agreements are no longer in force it is again open to those hospitals which have been approved to claim reimbursement. Clause 4 of the Bill would allow the Minister to revoke those approvals. In the absence of such a provision there would be no legal impediment to a duplication of funding as regards pharmaceutical benefits.

As Acting Minister for Health I announced that the amendments would allow the revocations to take effect from 16 September. I have written to State Health Ministers and advised them of the intention to introduce this amendment into the House.

As it is desired to provide discretionary powers to suspend or revoke approvals of hospital authorities it is intended that such power should rest with the Minister for Health. As a consequence it is appropriate for the power to approve hospital authorities to also rest with the Minister. Clause 4 of the Bill would effect a transfer of the power to approve hospital authorities from the permanent head to the Minister.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate declares that it is in accordance with the Constitution for the Senate to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981 by rejecting clause 6 of the Bill, and by leaving out other provisions of the Bill relating to the power of the Minister to make determinations under clause 6, or alternatively for the Senate to amend clause 6 of the Bill by requiring that any instrument signed by the Minister thereunder be approved by resolution of both Houses of the Parliament.

These education Bills, if I might use a loose expression, have been floating around now for some time. A number of propositions have been advanced and canvassed in relation to those Bills. It has been part of the burden of the Government's case-as I understand it, 'Stepp'd in so far that, . . . Returning were as tedious as go o'er' in these constitutional questions relating to the powers of the Senate-to suggest that the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981 is a money Bill which is not amendable. Let me say, firstly, that that is best illustrated by a comment made by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, during the brief debate we had about the suspension of Standing Orders to allow this motion to be debated. Senator Chaney, in the course of his comments about that matter, suggested that the Opposition had made a mistake, as it were, by marrying two propositions-one relating to the direct rejection of clause 6, which gives the Minister a power to make a declaration imposing fees, and the other, which is now identified with the Australian Democrats, in effect by way of amendment requiring the Minister to obtain the assent of both Houses of Parliament to any declaration imposing fees.

I remind the Senate that, in the course of debate when the Senate discussed these Bills previously, not only was it said by at least one Government speaker that the Government doubted the constitutional validity of rejecting clause 6 of the Bill, as has been the intention of the Opposition since this legislation was first introduced, but also the argument was canvassed by Senator Missen, as a Government senator-amongst others-in the context of the debate, that the proposition encapsulated in the amendment to be moved by the Democrats was not constitutional. That was argued on behalf of the Government. In response, we put both these matters in the motion of which I gave notice when the Senate previously discussed these matters.

If there is any substance in the Government's argument, it arises from section 53 of the Constitution which deals with the powers of the Houses in respect of legislation and proposed laws appropriating revenue or moneys or imposing taxation. Section 53 of the Constitution provides that:
The Senate may not amend proposed laws imposing taxation, or proposed laws appropriating revenue or moneys for the ordinary annual services of the Government.

I do not think it will be argued that this legislation is for the ordinary annual services of the Government; I do not think anybody would suggest that. It is not legislation which is even within the constitutional power of the Government. To argue that it has anything to do with the ordinary annual services of the Government would in those circumstances be a bizarre argument indeed.

If there is any strength to be gained from the provision in section 53 of the Constitution, upon which these bizarre notions which are being floated in an effort to muddy the waters about the constitutional power of the Senate are based, it arises from the next paragraph which states:
The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.

This Bill provides appropriation in respect of the functioning of universities and colleges of advanced education throughout Australia. Clause 6 of the Bill provides that the Minister for Education shall have a discretion in relation to the imposition of fees. If clause 6 is passed by the Senate, the Minister may never exercise that discretion. If he does not exercise that power of discretion, there is no question of his effecting, as it were, a proposed charge or a burden on the people. The Bills appropriate money for universities and colleges of advanced education. Nothing in clause 6 of this Bill has anything more than the most remote and tenuous connection with the imposition of any additional charge on the people. It is basically for those reasons, and consistent with the view that we have put about the powers of the Senate since the changed numbers came about, that the Opposition argues the proposal contained in the motion.

I make one other point. The Government, throughout this debate, has been looking for ways of saying that these are money Bills and that nothing can be done to amend these Bills. The suggestion has arisen only in the context of the Government's trying to reinforce a legislative program which is not the legislative program put to the people of Australia at the last election and trying to prop up and confuse the issues relating to this important question of the imposition of fees for second degrees in universities and colleges of advanced education. Of course, what flows from all that is the issue of the Government's credibility in relation to this argument which has been advanced, quite contrary to what was put in the context of the last election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the motion which has been moved by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, mainly because it requires the Senate to declare 'that it is in accordance with the Constitution for the Senate to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981 by rejecting clause 6 of the Bill, and by leaving out other provisions of the Bill relating to the power of the Minister to make determinations under clause 6'. The Leader of the Opposition stated in his argument in support of the motion that there was only a remote and tenuous connection between clause 6 and any proposed charge or burden on the people. I think there is only a remote and tenuous connection between that argument and the facts of the matter. I would have thought there would be far less interest in this provision if in fact it was genuinely thought in this chamber or elsewhere that there was little or no connection between what is provided in clause 6 and proposed charges or burdens on the people. The fact of the matter is that clause 6 is central to the Government's ability to do what has been clearly announced, which is to pass a portion of the burden of the cost of tertiary education back to those who are doing second degrees.
—But you announced it after the election, not before.

—I am not debating the point raised in that interjection. I am addressing the quality of clause 6 and what part it plays in the legislation which is before the chamber. As I said, that clause is central to the reduction in the charge or burden which is on the people with respect to tertiary education. Admittedly this is a relatively small proportion of the total Bill because it relates to that small minority of people who are doing second degrees, but it is quite clearly central and essential to the extent of the burden which rests upon the taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to refer very quickly to the scheme of the Bill. Clause 6 is the clause to which the motion relates. Clause 6 (1), in part, states:

. . . the Minister may, by instrument in writing . . . determine that each student who . . . undertakes at a relevant tertiary education institution studies of a kind specified in the determination should be charged by the institution, for each year in respect of which he undertakes studies of that kind, tuition fees at such rate (not exceeding $1,000 per annum), or of such amount (not exceeding $1,000), as specified in, or calculated in accordance with, the determination.
There are, of course, limitations placed on those students for whom fees can be applied in the later parts of clause 6.

I would like to refer now to clause 8 which, in common with other clauses which relate to other parts of the tertiary education system, gives the relevance of what is provided in clause 6 to the question of what charge or burden is going to be on the people. Clause 8 (1) provides:

In relation to each university specified in Column 1 of Schedule 1, there is payable to the State . . . for the purposes of financial assistance in relation to the expenditure of the university for university purposes in respect of a year to which this Act applies, the amount specified in Schedule 1 . . . reduced by such amount (if any) as the Minister determines under sub-section (2) to be the total of the appropriate tuition fees charges of that university in respect of that year.
Later clauses of the Bill provide for similar provisions related to courses in advanced education institutions and so on.

If one then turns to the appropriation clauses of the Bill one begins to see the relevance of section 53 of the Constitution which was referred to by Senator Button. Clause 51 of the Bill provides as follows:
The Consolidated Revenue Fund and the Loan Fund are appropriated as necessary for the purposes of this Act.

So there is a general appropriation under clause 51 of moneys for the purposes of the Act and the amount of moneys, as I have previously indicated, are those amounts which are set out in the schedule reduced by those amounts of the determinations under clause 6. Section 53 of the Constitution, to which reference has already been made, provides that where there are laws appropriating revenue or moneys-that is clearly relevant to this law which expressly in its terms does that-the Bill shall not originate in the Senate. Of course, this Bill has come from the House of Representatives, as it must. It goes on in the third paragraph, the paragraph essential to this argument, to say:
The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.

The effect of an amendment which would remove clause 6 would clearly be to ensure that the maximum amounts which are provided in the Schedules to this legislation would be the amounts which would have to be appropriated. Clearly if clause 6 remains in the legislation and becomes part of the Act, the amounts appropriated will be less than the amounts which are provided for in those Schedules. So it is in fact an argument of sophistry to suggest that the deletion of clause 6 will not result in an increased charge or burden upon the taxpayers of Australia. Of course, it must. The minimum amount of the Commonwealth expenditure under the Bill will be increased by the deletion, because if it is deleted there can be no reduction of the figures which are set out in the Schedule. It is the view of the Government, as it is the view of its advisers, that in fact the deletion of clause 6 would breach the third paragraph of section 53 of the Constitution.

I am aware, having now heard a number of these arguments in the Senate, that to some extent the logic of the argument is all very well. The late Senator Kennelly was reported to have said: 'Forget the logic and give me the numbers'. To a very great extent, whatever the logic of the position may be and whatever the strict legal position may be, it is possible for the Senate to carry whatever resolution it likes, including a resolution saying that black is white. But I suggest to the Senate that if one examines the provisions of this legislation and looks at the provisions of section 53 of the Constitution, one sees that it is clearly beyond the power of the Senate to remove this clause and that, therefore, this motion should not be passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting Senator Button's motion. I would like to outline the reasons why, because I believe not only the numbers but also the logic will be with Senator Button's motion. It is not an argument of sophistry, though it is an argument of technicality. May I just go through basically what the position is in relation to this Bill. The Constitution provides that the Senate may not amend any Bill so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people. This has been interpreted to mean that the Senate cannot amend any Bill to increase the amount of money appropriated in that Bill or to increase the expenditure which would be required by that Bill. Those were the points that I believe Senator Chaney was making in his speech when he maintained that this was that type of Bill. However, that is not the case for a very simple technical reason that I will come to in a moment. Basically the argument revolves around clause 6 of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill. Clause 6 says, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to this section, the Minister may . . .

The technicalities of saying 'he will' or 'he may', I do not think I have to explain to the Minister, but that clause actually says 'the Minister may'. It does not impose fees. It says that the Minister may impose fees. The removal of clause 6 from this Bill and the consequential removal of other provisions in the Bill associated with clause 6 do not have the effect of adding to the appropriation made by the Bill. Such amendments have the effect only of taking away from the Minister a power to determine the fees, if any, to be charged by institutions.

In other words, quite simply, the Bill is designed to set up a mechanism whereby the Minister may, if he so chooses and if the Government so wills, direct institutions to impose fees. Therefore, the appropriation associated with this Bill is the total amount without any reference whatsoever to the fees. The removal of the power of the Minister does not necessarily mean that the appropriation made by the Bill will be increased. It simply prevents the Minister from taking action which would have the ultimate effect of reducing the appropriation. That is a technical situation. Certainly we are arguing a technical matter here because we are arguing a number of items in relation to what the Senate may or may not do. I think it is not appropriate for the Minister to gloss over the fact that this Bill does not impose fees but merely allows the Minister to do so if he so chooses, and therefore the appropriation associated with this Bill is settled. If some subsequent action on the part of the Minister, and empowered by this Bill results in a reduction of that amount it would be at the Government's prerogative if this Bill were passed.

If one looks at the first part of Senator Button's motion one will see that the logic certainly is with him and not with the Government. I am indebted to Senator Button for adding the second part, although we would still maintain that, regardless of whether this Bill did increase those fees, the amendments I have already circulated do not bear at all on the appropriation, raised or lowered; they refer only to the determination and the mechanisms in relation to the determination. Therefore, we are indebted to him for including them for completion. I believe that others may be included to give a rounded view of what the Senate may believe is possible for it to do in relation to these Bills.

I wish to make one final point. We have taken exception already to the Government's introducing into its money Bills or Bills which otherwise are associated with money and charges certain new policies which it has not put to the electorate at any stage, which it has not tested. It now seeks to use the mechanism of tacking on to introduce new policies in what otherwise are Bills for the appropriation of moneys or, as with this Bill, making grants to universities. The compact that was made in 1967 in relation to money Bills has, I believe, stood until now. That compact was, I believe, a very important breakthrough. Indeed it was a compact drawn up solely by Government senators. In the section in relation to new policies they make a rather enlightened comment. They say that they consider that, as far as possible, the first provision for new policies should be in such a way as not to include them in Bills for other than the ordinary annual services of the government. They went on to say:

If such a practice were adopted, Parliament would be protected from the possibility of appropriations for any new policies not being readily identifiable in an omnibus appropriation Bill. Members of both Houses could then approach a consideration of the annual appropriations sure in the knowledge that only appropriations for services already approved were included . . .

In other words, in any new policy such as this, there ought to be a separate Bill, a separate debate and a separate resolution of this House and the Government should not seek, as it has done here and with other Bills, to tack on to other items-in this case items of incredible importance to this country-its new policies. We hope that in future the Government will bring in its new policies and let them stand or fall on their merits without seeking to entangle in its otherwise devious schemes the future of tertiary education in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As much as I and the Opposition admire the late Senator Kennelly, I would not wish it to be thought for a moment that in supporting this proposition tonight we are proceeding simply on the cynical assumption that if the numbers are likely there is no need to fuss about the logic. We have the logic on our side in this matter and I endorse everything in that respect that has been said by Senator Macklin. Perhaps even more can be said to make it absolutely clear for the record that there is no tinge of cynicism in the Opposition's intellectual support for this proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin by saying that on the face of it it is really quite extraordinary that an amendment expressly designed to reduce one form of burden or charge upon the people, namely tertiary fees, should be ruled out of order or argued to offend a provision of the Constitution on the ground that it amounts to an increase in a burden or charge upon the people. Sometimes we are so blurred by lawyers' convoluted reasoning that we overlook readings that stare us in the face in sections of this kind. It is some topsy-turvy, Alice in Wonderland-or Shirley in Wonderland-reasoning, on the face of it, to read the key provision in section 53 which states: 'The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people' and to say that by seeking to delete a charge or a burden on the people-tertiary fees-we are acting in breach of that provision.

To get the argument going in the way that Senator Chaney does one has to rely on a much more convoluted chain of lawyers' reasoning. One has to say that it is not a matter of the amendment itself increasing the burden; rather, it is a matter of the amendment-the removal of the provision in this case-creating conditions whereby more money may need to be spent pursuant to an appropriation than would otherwise be the case. That may in turn necessitate more money being raised by way of taxation. That is the way in which the clause has to be read even to begin to understand Senator Chaney's argument. Is that a proper way to read the provision? Does it have that kind of application so as to rule out constitutionally a direct amendment of the kind that has been proposed by the Opposition tonight to clause 6?

It is probably the case that that paragraph of section 53 operates so as to bite upon propositions to increase appropriations in some way. It is obviously the case that the paragraph we are talking about cannot be intended to apply to an attempted exercise by the Senate in increasing taxation, because attempts to increase taxation by this chamber are explicitly ruled out by other parts of section 53. Clearly, it is probably the case that the paragraph means that a fee or a licence charge, as distinct from a taxation provision which is the subject of a separate description in section 53, cannot be directly increased. If we in this chamber attempted to increase a fee or a licence of any description we would probably be in breach of this paragraph, so it clearly bites to that extent. It is clearly also the case that this paragraph of section 53 which provides that the Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people applies at least to certain categories of Appropriation Bills. It does not apply to appropriations for the ordinary annual services of the Commonwealth, because elsewhere in section 53 any playing about with those sorts of Appropriation Bills is expressly forbidden, but, of course, there are other categories of Appropriation Bills, that is, extraordinary or permanent Appropriation Bills, including the kind of Appropriation Bill we have before us tonight to provide for a States grants appropriation for tertiary education. It is probable that this paragraph in section 53 has some potential application to Appropriation Bills of that kind, so as to rule out the possibility of the Senate directly increasing an appropriation in a Bill of this kind.

To this extent I am with Senator Chaney, and the force of his argument which, on the face of it is implausible, begins to gain some momentum. I and, I suppose, the Opposition agree with page 671 of Quick and Garran, which is the test usually applied on these occasions, that while the Senate can vote to reduce on appropriation of the kind that is in issue in a States grants matter of this kind, it cannot vote to increase it. We accept that we could not fool about with any of the scheduled provisions to this Bill for the Townsville College of Advanced Education or any other institution so as to increase the amount appropriated for any particular tertiary institution or the total amount. That much is clear, but a question remains. It is the one to which we do have to address some logic in turning our attention back to clause 6 of the Bill which seeks to enable the Minister to set fees by way of Executive determination. Is the Senate, by deleting this clause, doing anything to increase the amount of the appropriation? Here I think the points that were taken by Senator Macklin and others in support of Senator Button's proposition are in fact well made.

The language in this key paragraph of section 53 says that the Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people. What is implied by those words is some direct nexus, I would suggest, between the Senate amending the proposition in question and the actual increase in the appropriation that is involved. There is no such direct nexus here because clause 6, as Senator Macklin has very clearly said and as Senator Chaney completely ignored in his presentation, is not a mandatory provision. The clause does not require a determination that tertiary fees be set. It is left entirely within the discretion of the Minister. He may impose fees. There is no certainty that he will impose fees even under this Government if its political courage fails it over the next few months if it does happen to get this Bill passed. If this clause does stay in the Bill it is possible that the Minister will take no action. If he does take no action no financial consequenes of any kind will follow from the retention of this clause or equally from its removal.

But of course it will be said, as it was said by Senator Chaney-I do think we have to follow the next stage of the argument-that we have to look at clause 8(1.) of the Bill which requires that the grants to tertiary institutions be reduced by the amount of any fee which does happen to be imposed pursuant to that determination if it does happen to be made. That means that if a fee is not imposed the grant from the Commonwealth under the appropriation will have to stay at the ceiling level that is provided in the Schedule and so the argument goes that accordingly the taxpayers will to that extent be disadvantaged. But I think there are two propositions which count against that reading, bringing us within the scope of section 53. The first is that moneys have already been appropriated by this Bill up to a ceiling level. No additional appropriation could be contemplated as a result of fees in fact not being imposed. The Government cannot increase the appropriation above the level which is already provided for by the text of this Bill. Of course there is no suggestion that anything involved in the Opposition's amendment that is proposed to clause 6 will amount to such an increase in the actual dollar sum of the appropriation beyond the ceiling level that is set.

The other point that needs to be made about this is that clause 8, as is the case in respect of clause 6-and I think this point again was made by Senator Macklin-is entirely discretionary too. It is not obligatory upon the Government or whoever is administering this scheme in fact to reduce the amount of the appropriation that is in fact directed to the State in question in the event that a determination is made and fees are in fact imposed. It is just creating the possibility for that to happen. One might say as a practical matter that there is a likelihood that it will happen as a matter of Government policy but it is not a direct nexus. There is not a direct flow from the imposition of a fee to the reduction of the appropriation-the direct grant to the institution-by that amount. It is our argument that there would have to be that direct relationship if one is even to begin to get an argument going relying on that paragraph in section 53.

The only other thing I want to say relates to precedents, such as they are, in this area. I suggest that such precedents as there are and as we have been able to turn up are of no help whatsoever to the Government. It is true that the matter was debated very early in the life of the national Parliament back in the 1901-1903 session as recorded by Geoffrey Sawer at page 31 in the first volume of his Australian Federal Politics and Law. There was a debate on a sugar bounty Bill, a long and learned and eventually somewhat inconclusive debate. During that debate various propositions were put down and uncontested on either side to the effect, for example, that if a particular appropriation came forward to the Senate providing for a single track railway between two cities-presumably interstate-and the Senate insisted on changing the basis of the authorisation so as to provide for a double track there would be such a direct nexus between that policy change and the obvious additional appropriation that would be necessary that that would amount to a burden on the people such as to bring it within the scope of that paragraph in section 53, such as to make it not something that was able to be put by way of amendment but only by way of request. So we have a suggestion in one of those very early debates that a sort of circumstance could apply in this way. But I suggest that that is of no help to the Government tonight considering the facts that are before us.

Equally, there was another debate in 1932-the only other early precedent which seems to exist anywhere-involving the Financial Emergency Act. Senator Colebatch moved an amendment which was passed by the Senate. Without going into all the sordid and boring details, there was an amendment to a gold bounty Bill whereby the gold producers were guaranteed an additional income supplement by way of bounty even if the international price of gold fell. Clearly, that was contemplating a direct additional drain on the Treasury. By virtue of that amendment the House of Representatives quite understandably jacked up about that. It said: 'You cannot do that by way of amendment. That offends the paragraph in section 53'. The Senate accepted that argument. Those seem to have been the only two early precedents. Both of them give some sort of nourishment to the notion that that paragraph in section 53 can bite in certain circumstances where one is doing something which necessarily inexorably would result in an increased appropriation. But I suggest that neither of them helps the Government tonight.

I have been able to turn up one other example which directly hinders the case that the Government is moving tonight. That is an argument which arose under the Social Services Amendment Bill of very recent memory, in this place on 27 April 1976, involving a small matter of funeral benefits. It may be recalled that this Government, with its usual delicacy and sensitivity, proposed to remove the funeral benefit that was payable to pensioners. There was then a successful excise, that may be recalled by some honourable senators, in this place to remove the particular provisions in the Social Services Amendment Bill which enabled the removal of the funeral benefit. An argument was assiduously mounted, not in this chamber but in the Press and all round the place, to the effect that, as part of the psychological warfare that preceded this enterprise it was, in fact, unconstitutional for the Senate to do this. It was argued that anything that would retain the payment of funeral benefits would thereby amount to an additional drain upon the Treasury beyond that which was contemplated by the Government's legislation. As such it was the kind of thing that could not be advanced. When Senator Grimes got up in this place to move, as he did in the Committee stage on 27 April 1976, that the Bill moved by the Government be amended so as to retain the provision for funeral benefits there was not a bark from the Government benches. There was not a suggestion raised-

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got it wrong. The clauses were beaten; that is all. He did not move anything at all.
—I refer to page 1277 of the Hansard where Senator Grimes is recorded as having said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . some doubt has been expressed as to whether the Senate has the power to oppose this clause.

There was doubt as to whether the Senate had the power to take out a clause which would have resulted in the removal of the funeral benefit payment. I have checked this out technically. That was the context in which the matter came before this Parliament. It demanded an affirmative vote in order to remove the benefit-an affirmative vote which was made by the Senate. The suggestion had been canvassed all round the place that it was not constitutionally competent for the Senate to make such an affirmative vote except by way of request. But when it came to the point, because the Government knew that it would be defeated on the issue and did not want to be seen to be raising a churlish procedural point, the Government remained silent. It did not take the constitutional point which it claims tonight is so clearly available to it. The reality of the matter is that the Government's conception of constitutional law and constitutional propriety shows to this chamber a flexibility that is reminiscent of the morals of an old whore. It will do absolutely what is necessary to advance an argument to suit its immediate political cause, whether or not it believes in the intellectual integrity of the particular argument that is thus being advanced. On careful rational analysis such as I have endeavoured to advance, along with Senator Macklin, this provision and the way it has been applied in the past there is simply no logical justification or foundation for the argument that the Government is seeking to con us with tonight.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly simply to refute a statement made by Senator Macklin that the Government had in some precedent way tacked on fees conditions to a money Bill and that there was something unusual about it. I suggest that evidence will show that that is not so. The facts are that Commonwealth grants to the States for education purposes are classified as section 96 specific purpose payments and provided through States grants legislation. Any requirement by the Commonwealth that particular policies should be followed has been implemented by attaching conditions of grants to those specific purpose payments. This practice has been adopted in relation to a wide range of policy issues in previous States grants education legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Of particular significance in regard to tuition fees is that it should be noted that the 1973 amendment to the States Grants (Universities) Act included a provision, as a condition of grant, that required the States to ensure that tuition fees would not be charged at universities and colleges of advanced education or in regular technical and further education courses. That, I think, was a Whitlam Government amendment. The provisions in the present States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill for the limited reintroduction of tuition fees are consistent with that approach as that Bill places an obligation on the States to ensure that relevant institutions do not charge any student fees 'otherwise than in accordance with the conditions' set out elsewhere in the legislation. Any claim that the Government is tacking on to a money Bill matters which are not properly in a money Bill therefore clearly is inaccurate. The Government's proposals in relation to the limited reintroduction of tuition fees and the other matters of policy in this Bill are being treated in a way which is entirely consistent with the approach taken for many years in States grants legislation in the education area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what Senator Carrick has said requires an answer. He has said certain things are so but I do not believe he has demonstrated that is the case. The question of the application of section 53 is much more important than this Bill. It transcends it because it is a general principle which may affect the Senate in years to come. Basically what can happen, going on Senator Chaney's logic, is that the Government can take almost anything-most things in this world cost money-and set it against an appropriation in a money Bill and then say that because things cost money and the relevant legislation is not passed the appropriation will be increased, or not reduced, as in the case of this Bill. I suggest that that is a totally spurious interpretation of section 53 of the Constitution, and if it were permitted by the Senate it would create a situation where the Senate virtually would surrender all its powers to debate or discuss anything. I think it really goes to that reasoning.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take another couple of examples which occur to me in a non-legal sense. For instance, if there were an amendment in the Senate preventing the sale of a Commonwealth asset, that would cost the community more. Would section 53 apply to that? An amendment requiring even a single hour's work by a public servant could be said to cost the public money and that some appropriation somewhere might have to be increased to cover it. Would section 53 apply to that? It could be said that an amendment improving some piece of defence equipment which might cost a trifling sum more would increase an appropriation. Is the Senate then not to deal with any of these matters?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion by Senator Button which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate declares that it is in accordance with the Constitution for the Senate to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981 by rejecting clause 6 of the Bill, and by leaving out other provisions of the Bill relating to the power of the Minister to make determinations under clause 6, or alternatively for the Senate to amend clause 6 of the Bill by requiring that any instrument signed by the Minister thereunder be approved by resolution of both Houses of the Parliament.

I propose to move an amendment to that motion. Before I do so, I just refer briefly to some of the matters that have been put forward in support of that proposition and indicate that I would have thought that the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill was a Bill under the provisions of section 96 of the Constitution. Section 96 of the Constitution provides:

During a period of ten years after the establishment of the Commonwealth and thereafter until the Parliament otherwise provides, the Parliament may grant financial assistance to any State on such terms and conditions as the Parliament thinks fit.

I would have thought that that is pretty plain. That can be related to section 57 of the Constitution and the proposition that has been put forward by Senator Button in respect of the power of the Senate and in respect of paragraph 3 of section 53 of the Constitution which states:
The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.
I concur with what Senator Button said. Part of the proposition, of course, is to include a provision wherein the Minister may make a determination. But, as Senator Button said, he may not.
Seeing that we are carrying a motion as to our powers, I thought that we might add another one. Therefore, I move:

At end of motion add: ', or alternatively for the Senate to divide the Bill so as to incorporate in a separate Bill the provisions relating to the imposition of certain fees by tertiary institutions'.

I think that it is very important that the Senate at some stage makes a declaration that we can assert our right under paragraph 33D of our Standing Orders to divide a Bill in the Committee of the Whole. This proposal, of course, was foreshadowed by me during the debate on the sales tax measure. Whilst this matter still remains on the Notice Paper, it will be revised when the sales tax measure comes back to this chamber so as to enable honourable senators to exercise a vote to ensure that parts of the Bill thus divided will be rejected in accordance with the majority wishes of the Senate. It is to be hoped that those honourable senators who are prepared to go to the barricades over this addition of tuition fees will support that proposition and, of course, ensure the blocking of the sales tax provisions on essential commodities. I think it is important for this Parliament to assert its rights in respect of this proposed law and to assert them by including and agreeing to that addendum to the motion. It goes without saying that at any stage the Senate has the right to make requests to the House of Representatives on this or any other Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with that.
—Sure, it may even do so. One never knows.
—Why bother fussing about this?

—Does the honourable senator want to move a motion to make a request to the House of Representatives; it might save me doing it? The Senate obviously has that power in respect of this Bill. Before the debate is concluded, it might well do so. I simply desire to point out to honourable senators that it would be appropriate at this stage, seeing that we are making it clear to the Government and to the people of Australia that we have certain rights, to include that other right of division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill, which is now before the Senate, appropriates some $2 billion for the support of universities and colleges. Clause 6, which relates to the partial reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees, as has been indicated by the second reading speeches that we have heard, is controversial and there is now before us a motion that it is constitutional for the Senate to amend the Bill, and in particular to delete clause 6.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, the debate is about the interpretation of sections of the Constitution in deciding whether the motion in relation to clause 6 may be passed. If the debate leads the Senate to accept the motion presumably the Senate fortified by that acceptance, would go on to amend clause 6 or even to delete it, thus taking from the Bill the provision which would impose a partial reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees. It is not a light matter because it is estimated that the passage of clause 6 would lead to the raising of $8m in fees in the calendar year 1982. Moreover, after a period of three years-the fee will not be imposed on any student who is currently enrolled for a post-graduate or second degree, or a diploma; only a student first enrolling today and meeting the criteria set down will be liable-we will come closer to a steady state situation in which according to Government estimates, the revenue to be raised annually will total $20m. Clause 8, as Senator Evans has shown, specifies that that $8m revenue derived in 1982, or the $20m estimated revenue derived in 1984, will be deducted--

TALK.START.PARA: —May be deducted.

—I understand clause 8 to say that it will be deducted-from the moneys appropriated by this Bill. Thus, if we deleted clause 6 we would be changing the burden on the people. The revenue of the Government would be diminished by $8m for calendar year 1982 and $20m for calendar year 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button and Senator Macklin argued that clause 6 did not impose any such burden; that it merely gave power to the Minister to make a determination and that such determination would impose the burden. They argued that therefore it was quite within the terms of section 53 of the Constitution for the Senate to deny to the Minister the power to make such determination. I regard that argument as entirely tenuous and not sustainable.

Surely we can come to the principle of the matter, which is that this is the provision that gives the Minister the power to impose such a fee. I believe that therefore the argument put forward by Senator Button and Senator Macklin falls flat. I am not at all impressed by it. Senator Evans did not take that line. He first tried to argue that the fees themselves were a burden upon the people; that by denying the Minister the power to levy such fees upon this small proportion of tertiary students we would be lessening the burden upon the people. I think that is rather Irish.

TALK.START.PARA: —Welsh.

—All right, it is Welsh, but he does not see that if the fees were not levied that burden would fall universally upon all of the people who were making any contribution to government revenue. I do not believe that his argument meets the point of section 53 of the Constitution.
—It is 'burden on the people', not 'burden on the taxpayers'. That is the language.

—It is 'burden on the people'. Sure, the fees that are levied on some 8,000 people in 1982 or 20,000 people in 1984 will be a burden upon those people. I agree to that extent. But that amount of revenue would automatically be raised from a much wider proportion of the Australian people through general taxation revenues if it were not raised as proposed and as such deductible from the appropriation made under this Bill. So I regard that Welsh argument as not convincing either.
—That is double-dutch.

—Whether it is Welsh, Irish or Dutch, I point out that there is an imposition on the people in one way or the other. Senator Harradine has raised the question of section 96 of the Constitution. I understand that this Bill is based upon the powers given in the Constitution to this Parliament to grant financial assistance to States on any condition that the Parliament sees to be fit. On that argument, if that were the only section in the Constitution that had any relevance at all to this matter, then section 96 of the Constitution would allow the Parliament to pass this motion. Section 96 states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Parliament may grant financial assistance to any State on such terms and conditions as the Parliament thinks fit.

However, it is still my view that section 96 of the Constitution does not deny section 53 of the Constitution. I am not arguing now with Senator Harradine. Section 53 still stands and still should be the guide in this matter. The key paragraph is the third paragraph of section 53, which states:
The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.

That paragraph may be interpreted one way or the other. Several lawyers have preceded me in this debate. I do not profess, as some of them do, to be an expert on the various precedents of interpretation of the Constitution on this matter. Having sought in my speech to debunk the arguments put by Senators Button and Macklin and half of what Senator Evans said, I believe that the case rests entirely on the third paragraph of section 53 of the Constitution. It is on that question alone that I believe that we ought to determine the motion by Senator Button that is before us. I repeat that the third paragraph in section 53 states:
The Senate may not amend any proposed law-
Including the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill-
so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.

I believe that to so amend the legislation would require in the year ahead of us an extra burden or charge on the people of Australia of $8m, or in three years time an amount of $20m. It is for that reason and that reason alone that I oppose the motion moved by Senator Button.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the Government proposes to oppose the amendment moved by Senator Harradine and to outline briefly why that amendment is to be opposed. There are two grounds on which the Government does not find the amendment acceptable. The first is constitutional grounds. Effectively, a division of the Bill would achieve the result which we say, under section 53 of the Constitution, should not be achieved by amendment or deletion of a section. If the Bill is split it ceases to be a single Bill and each of the new Bills is, by definition, discreet and an amended form of the former Bill. The reality of that is borne out by the fact that the Senate could choose to deal with the separate Bills in whatever way it chose. It could pass both; it could reject both; it could reject one and pass one and so on. Each of the Bills is different in substance from the original. If, therefore, one accepts that section 53 precludes the amendment of a proposed law, it also precludes the splitting of a proposed law in the way which might be proposed in this case. Quite apart from that, the problem that I think the Senate would face in splitting a Bill of this type is that the clauses which relate to the charging of fees are truly an integral part of the Bill. There are, of course, very few precedents for the procedure which is being suggested as being appropriate by this amendment. The Standing Order is, of course, a fairly bare provision. It simply says that there may be a splitting of the Bill. If one looks at Erskine May's Parliamentary Practice one will see some reference to the division of Bills. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . such an instruction is in order only if the bill is drafted in two or more distinct parts, or else, comprising more than one subject matter, lends itself to such division into parts.
Under the heading 'Impracticable division of bill', it states:

. . . an instruction to divide a bill into two or more bills is only in order if the bill is drafted in two or more distinct parts, or else, comprising more than one subject-matter, lends itself to such division.

If one looks at the actual structure of this Bill, one will see quite clearly that a whole series of provisions flow and follow from clause 6. I think the precise number of amendments which would be required by any deletion of clause 6 would be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty-nine.

—It is 29, is it? I was about to put a slightly lower figure on it. In any event, there would be a substantial number of amendments. I think that alone demonstrates that this is not the sort of Bill where, even if it were constitutionally possible, one would go along with the procedure of dividing.
—There are no precedents in the Senate at all for this.

—No, there are not and there are very limited precedents elsewhere. There is a South Australian precedent and a Tasmanian precedent. I do not want to say too much more because Senator Evans will probably get up and talk about them at great length. It is quite clear, on the face of this Bill, that it is not the sort of legislation which lends itself to division. For that reason, as well as for the constitutional reason, the Government will oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate briefly that the Opposition would support the amendment moved by Senator Harradine. The words 'surprise, surprise' have been uttered already in the Senate, so I do not think it is necessary for anybody to do it again. In relation to the particular Bills, we share the view which has been expressed by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). The Opposition considered this course of action. We felt that in the circumstances of the particular Bills--
—This motion refers to 'the Bill'.

In the particular circumstances of this Bill it is not, if I can lapse into the vernacular for a minute, one which grabs us.

—Yes.
—I would have thought that if that was your view you would not agree with the amendment.

—You only have to be right one in three times.

—I thank Senator Teague. I shall deal briefly with the arguments that have been advanced against the proposition which is now before the Senate. First of all, I think the quality of a debate can be judged not always so much by the things which are said in it but rather by the things which are not said in it. Let us look at the point at issue in relation to the constitutional power and the provisions of clause 6 of the Bill before the Senate. This issue has not been dealt with by Government spokesmen. It is simply that clause 6 of the Bill provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to this section, the Minister may, by instrument in writing signed by him, determine . . .
It provides that he may determine that fees be charged. The paragraph of section 53 of the Constitution upon which every speaker in this debate has relied states simply:
the Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.
It is a very long time since I studied constitutional law, but I recall something about going straight to the essence of the particular instrument which one is examining.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was cooking, not constitutional law.

—Senator Chaney tells me that that was cooking. I learned cooking too, but I am asking Senator Chaney to refresh his memory on constitutional law. The essence of the constitutional provision is a prohibition on the Senate's amending any proposed law which seeks to increase a charge or burden on the people. This proposed law, clause 6 of this Bill, is not a matter which goes to that question at all. It is an enabling provision which would give the Minister a discretion which he may never exercise. It goes to the question of the Minister's power. That is what clause 6 of this Bill is about and that is what--
—Senator Evans strayed a bit from that line, didn't he?

—I point out to Senator Missen that I am not here to play a disciplinarian role. But I notice that Senator Missen, like every other honourable senator on the Government side, having his constitutional laurels to protect, does not dissent from the view I have just put; that is, that the essence of clause 6 is to do with the question of power and the discretion of the Minister and not to do with the question of raising a charge on the people.

SPEECH.PARA: I am indebted to Senator Carrick for his entry into the debate. He suggested in reply to Senator Macklin that nothing would be further from this Government's mind than tacking this provision onto this Bill; that nothing would be further from the mind of this Government of the utmost probity than to indulge in a naughty little trick like that. Let us look at this Government's record on fees. Time and again in this place Senator Carrick has assured the people of Australia that the Fraser Government would not introduce fees. What did it do about overseas students' fees? Senator Carrick gave an undertaking that no fees would be imposed on overseas students. How did the Government slide out of that undertaking? It slid out of it by calling them visa charges instead of university fees. The Government could not stick to its promise so it went about imposing fees by the tortuous route of imposing visa charges on overseas students coming to Australia. They were called visa charges instead of fees because the Government had promised again and again that it would not introduce fees for overseas students. That was a slippery tactic that was relied upon on that occasion.

On this occasion, the Government would take any step possible to break a commitment which was made by its Minister for Education prior to the last election. That is the context of the whole debate tonight. This is not really a debate about constitutional power. It is a debate about the Government's credibility and that is the context in which the debate has been conducted tonight. It is just interesting that that note of humbug should be revealed in the context of this debate. As I have said, the real issues on the constitutional point have not been addressed. That the words proposed to be added (Senator Harradine's amendment) be added.
