SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 11, clause 6, after sub-clause (6), insert the following sub-clause:
(6A)(a) An instrument signed by the Minister under this section shall be laid before each House of the Parliament within 5 sitting days of that House after the signing of the instrument.
(b) Any instrument which is not laid before each House of the Parliament in accordance with paragraph (a) shall be void and of no effect.

(c) An instrument laid before each House of the Parliament in accordance with paragraph (a) shall be deemed to have been revoked at the expiration of 10 days after the instrument has been laid before both Houses of the Parliament unless each House of the Parliament has by resolution declared that the instrument is approved.

I believe the proposition in this amendment is one of principle; that is, that when we seek to delegate important areas of legislation such areas should in fact be overseen by the Parliament so that any action taken can be revised. I believe that the need for and the value of parliamentary control over legislation are accepted and have been accepted by this chamber. I believe that the elected Parliament should retain the ultimate responsibility for the law. The Executive, of course, has a different approach to the law than that of the Parliament. It tends to regard administrative convenience as the principal criterion of government. Administrative convenience, of course, is a necessary and legitimate aim of government. Nevertheless, we believe that parliamentary control should be brought to bear on all delegated legislation so that the legitimate rights and liberties of the citizens, which are the responsibility of the elected members of parliament, are protected.

The particular method that is incorporated in the amendment I have moved is the strongest form of parliamentary control of delegated legislation that exists in the Westminster system, and that is the affirmation by Parliament. The point of the affirmation is a simple one, and that is that the Government has to put any instrument signed on the Notice Paper, it has to provide for time for debate, and it has to put its reasons to the Parliament as to why it wishes to engage in some particular activity that is allowed under the legislation. The point in relation to clause 6 is that if the Minister wishes to impose fees-we have already had a fairly extensive debate about the fact that this is merely a discretionary clause and does not mean that the Minister is going to do anything-when the amounts he wishes to charge are settled, the Parliament will debate the issue and make a decision in relation to the determination made by the Minister. In other words, Parliament will have control over the legislation, particularly in this area.

I am indebted to Senator Missen for drawing my attention to the conference on delegated legislation held here last year at which members of the Commonwealth parliaments met and discussed this issue at some length. One of the interesting points raised by members of the delegation from the House of Commons was that they tend to use this approach of affirmative resolution in relation to the imposition of financial charges. It seems to me that this is an appropriate point to bring before the Parliament the suggestion that we ought to move from the method which we currently employ to the much more forceful and stronger method of affirmative approval of Parliament.

Finally, I would like to quote a rather interesting point made by Senator Evans at that conference which I believe applies not only to the Government but also to parties aspiring to be in government. He said:

The reality is that executive governments, however brave they have been when in opposition, and the bureaucrats who serve them, will mount a rear-guard action unto the death when it comes to resisting really significant reforms of this kind.

I believe that we will have a fight to the death actually to get such a reform, but I believe this is an appropriate point at which to start the debate. Our amendment has been moved in the spirit that this is obviously an area of extreme importance to the community. It is one upon which the community is divided as to its worth or otherwise; it is one upon which this House has already shown it is divided as to its worth. It seems to me appropriate that, if the Minister is to make determinations under this clause, they should not stand alone but should get the support of both Houses of Parliament before they become a charge on the citizens of this country. I commend the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on this amendment. I appreciate that Senator Macklin has raised a question which, in a broader context, I think is quite important, namely, the idea that affirmative resolutions might be used more extensively. We have used them on very rare occasions in some of the legislation of this Parliament, and it is true that the Conference on Delegated Legislation which met here last year and the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, of which I am Chairman, strongly urged that they should be used more often in the Parliament. But I think they should be used in important areas and with regard to important questions, and I am not sure that this is a suitable occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: The question here, as I understand it, is not whether fees should be imposed but whether by this clause the Minister should be empowered to make determinations, with the secondary question-whether they will come into operation-to be determined by the Parliament. it is fairly obvious that there is objection to this provision, and I have a great deal of sympathy with that objection. But I do not think it is necessarily right to suggest that this is an appropriate occasion on which to apply an affirmative resolution. Of course, one understands that, when a party has members in only one House of the Parliament, such a proposal natural would have a little more attraction because it would then be in the hands of either of the Houses to take the action and it would have to be approved by both Houses. But I suggest to the Senate that this is not an important area so far as this decision is concerned.

The decision whether the clause stays will obviously be made here and elsewhere. A situation in which there would be power to require the making of declarations which will then have to be debated again in both Houses is, I think, an unnecessary addition to the way in which the process should be performed. I do not think that this is a suitable occasion for the application of the affirmative method. I do not want my opposition to this proposal to be taken as my saying that I do not think it should ever be used. I think it should be used much more often, but it should be used on important questions on which it is necessary and desirable to have the opinion of both Houses of the Parliament. For that reason, I do not think this is the right occasion.

We have many reservations about the argument put forward by Senator Macklin that this is a suitable occasion on which to apply the principle of delegated legislation. We do not consider that this is an appropriate use of the power of delegation. We consider that it would be a most clumsy and cumbersome machinery for arriving at a certain end. As well as our machinery reservations, of course, we cannot support the amendment because it does not contradict the purposes of clause 6. The amendment continues within the legislation the power to impose fees on tertiary students, and the Federal Opposition is opposed to that provision. So I indicate on behalf of the Opposition that we will not support Senator Macklin's amendment. We will continue our outright opposition to clause 6 and we will vote accordingly. I indicate too that, in order that the legislation be workable without clause 6, the Opposition has prepared and had circulated a series of amendments which are consequential on the deletion of clause 6 and which I will move on behalf of the Opposition at the completion of the Committee stage of the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -I can see the reasoning behind the proposed amendments to clause 6. It is to provide to the Parliament the ultimate scrutiny of precisely what form the instrument would take. However, I would differ with the proposer of the motion, Senator Macklin, as there is merit in something that Senator Missen said. I understood him to indicate that there is a responsibility on both Houses of Parliament. If there is one group of persons in only one House, it can be seen that that group would seek to have incorporated into legislation safeguard and watchdog provisions which would ensure that it would have a final examination of the proposal. If there were a watchdog provision similar to that which is provided for regulations and ordinances, namely, that within 15 days of them being laid on the table either House of Parliament may disallow them, I think that would be a neater way of dealing with this matter. However, on balance, if the Bill is to go through in its current state, I agree that the Parliament ought to look at the instrument or, if that is not possible, it should at least get some indication from the Minister as to precisely what would be included in the instrument. At this stage I think I would support the proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is necessary for me to indicate that I have had discussions with quite a number of people about the proposed reintroduction of fees for second degrees and post-graduate study at universities. I have been impressed by the submissions that have been made to me by representatives from the University of Tasmania and from the Students Representative Council in that State. I also have been particularly impressed by a letter which was sent to me from the chairman of the School of Physics at the University of Melbourne, Professor E. G. Muirhead. I would like to read this letter to the Senate because I think it is important for some distinctions to be drawn. Professor Muirhead wrote about the reintroduction of tertiary fees and said:
. . . Senator Harradine,

I am reminded of your concern for this matter by the recent article in THE AUSTRALIAN HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPLEMENT . . . and hope that you might find the following information both relevant and significant.
This School of Physics-
That is, the University of Melbourne School of Physics.

trains postgraduate students for both M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees. It is the largest Physics postgraduate school in Australia with approximately 60 students at present. Of these, ten (10) students are pursuing their studies without scholarships. There is an annual intake of about 5 such students. Many of these subsequently gain a postgraduate scholarship as a consequence of demonstrably superior performance as researchers. All students in this 'unsupported' category subsist on money earned from up to 6 hours/week in part-time teaching as tutors or laboratory demonstrators, yielding approximately $1,500 p.a.

This amount has to be supplemented by support from parents, or other part-time jobs, etc. It should be noted that students on scholarships also seek this remuneration in order to supplement the inadequate level of postgraduate awards which have not been indexed for inflation.

It has been universally accepted that postgraduate students have reached such a level of competence at the attainment of their B.Sc. (Honours) degree as to be contributing a most significant amount of research within each university department and consequently merit a living allowance. The situation has something in common with the scheme of apprenticeship training. In each case there is something to be gained by the individual, the employer and ultimately society at large.

It seems to many of us a wholly retrograde step to single out this small group of students for maximum discouragement as a consequence of the proposed re-imposition of fees. One immediate effect of the latter will be to significantly reduce the annual intake of students in this category by an amount which can only be guessed e.g. in our example from the present 5/25 or 20% p.a. to perhaps 2/22 or 9% p.a. This will occur at a time when there is a demonstrable need for physicists in our technologically based society. All the evidence available to us, both from surveys reported through the Australian Institute of Physics and from the follow-up histories of our own graduates indicates that they find congenial employment consistent with their qualifications. There remain two points which ought to be given weight in considering this matter of fees.

I will not read those points. The letter goes on to the question of providing a further tax base for those people who do post-graduate work. It states that in their future employment they will be able to contribute substantially because of their enhanced income ability. It then refers to undergraduate records and so on. I seek leave to have the rest of the letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

1. Any small immediate financial gain through their imposition is likely to be offset by the long term reduction in taxation revenue due to a reduced number of graduates who over their professional working life would have more than repayed the community for the direct cost of their university course(s) either through increased productivity or higher levels of personal income tax, or both. The cost-effectiveness of the proposed scheme should first be established.

2. The background of the group of initially unsupported postgraduate students is of interest. Their undergraduate records are better than average (65-70%) which partly explains their inability to obtain a Commonwealth Postgraduate Award (or equivalent University Postgraduate Award) for which considerable weight is given to the level of the third year results in the B.Sc. course. Their subsequent history in the B.Sc. (Honours) and M.Sc. years, in which research is a large component, shows that the majority mature and develop considerably and finally complete good quality M.Sc. or Ph.D. theses which compare very favourably with those produced by those on awards. While our sample of students may be small I am confident that the conclusions drawn will hold for the group at large.

In conclusion therefore may I commend for your consideration and concern the very negative consequence of the proposed tertiary fees both for Australia and for a significant number of postgraduates who do not derserve to be penalized relative to their peers.
Yours sincerely, (E. G. Muirhead) Chairman, School of Physics

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise this matter because I think it is important to focus on the real issue in relation to the impostion of fees, that is, its effect particularly on post-graduate students.
—The fourth category of post-graduate students; not all post-graduate students.

—I am talking about those post-graduate students who are doing masters' degrees or PhDs. In other words, they are persons in a particular area of learning who are going on to a higher level and who are doing the research which many of the universities now say will be drastically affected as a result of the imposition of fees on those people. I apologise to honourable senators for raising the matter at this stage. Obviously I was not able to do so during the second reading debate but, on balance, I will support the proposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

Those currently enrolled in post-graduate study who have not got a Commonwealth post-graduate award, a university research grant or a significant scholarship will not have fees imposed on them either. It will be only those new ones.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many private hospitals in Australia are now foreign owned.
(2) What are the names and locations of these hospitals, and the names of their foreign proprietors.

(3) How many applications have been made to the Foreign Investment Review Board by United States Corporations seeking permission to operate private hospitals in Australia; and how many of these applications have been successful.
(4) Was the Insurance Company of North America (Australia) Limited incorporated in New South Wales in October 1978.
(5) Does this company have a number of subsidiary companies operating in Australia concerned with various medical areas including insurance, medical management and rehabilitation.

(6) Does such vertical integration of health services carry with it the inherent danger of 'self-referral'; that is, the referral of a patient by one section of a medical conglomerate to another section; if so, what steps does the Minister for Health propose to take in order to ensure that the danger of such self-referral, and the concomitant danger of over-prescription of services and drugs, is minimised in Australia.

(7) May these developments be associated with the intrusion of the profit motive into the Australian health-care system; if so, will the Minister affirm that medical services in Australia must be rendered out of a central concern for the patient's need, rather than for the ultimate purpose of earning private profits.

(8) Are there any loopholes in the Foreign Takeovers Act which could allow Australian private hospital proprietors registered under the Companies Act to lease their right to operate hospitals to foreign interests.
(9) Is the Minister aware of any case in which this has been done.

(10) Must foreign takeovers of private hospitals with assets of less than $2 000 000 be examined by the Foreign Investment Review Board; if not, is the Minister aware of any cases in which such takeovers have occurred.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) Approvals given to U.S. firms to invest in private hospitals in Australia up to 4 March 1980 are set out in the answer to Senate Question No. 2024, (Hansard, 4 March 1980, p. 537). Since that date approval has been given to Hospital Affiliates of Australia Pty Ltd to acquire the Bundoora and District private hospital, a 70-bed medical/surgical hospital near Melbourne. One other approval was given for a further acquisition by Hospital Corporation Australia Pty Ltd but this proposal was not implemented for commercial reasons. Hospital Corporation Australia Pty Ltd has also recently advised the Government that it has withdrawn from the Noarlunga District private hospital project at Christies Beach, South Australia. The only other private hospital known to have foreign equity in it is the President Private Hospital in Sydney, owned as to 25 per cent by Commonwealth Industrial Gases Ltd (see answer to Senate Question No. 2552, Hansard, 20 May 1980, p. 2544). All proposals by foreign interests to invest in private hospitals have been examined in consultation with the relevant State health authorities. All such proposals have been approved subject to conditions that the companies concerned meet the requirements of relevant health authorities and introduce a minimum of 35 per cent local equity into their Australian operations.
(4) The INA Insurance Company of Australia was incorporated on 17 October 1978. The name of this company was changed to Insurance Company of North America (Australia) Ltd on 24 November 1978.

(5) The Insurance Company of North America (Australia) Ltd's legal representative has advised that Hospital Affiliates Australia Pty Ltd which is wholly owned by the company's U.S. parent, owns five private hospitals in Australia. However, the U.S. parent has, subject to Australian Government approval under the provisions of the Foreign Takeovers Act, reached agreement to sell these hospitals to National Medical Enterprises Inc. of the U.S.A. The company is also planning to establish a new subsidiary to provide rehabilitation services on a consultancy basis.

(6) and (7) In relation to the Commonwealth's powers and responsibilities medical services should be only those that are reasonably necessary for the adequate medical care of the patients concerned. This principle is set out in the definition of 'excessive services' in the Health Insurance Act. The principle applies to services provided by private practitioners, which are eligible for medical benefits, or to services provided in other situations, such as in hospitals or health centres. The Government has taken a number of initiatives to control the provisions of unnecessary services or fraudulent claims. My Department has developed a large computer based fraud and overservicing detection system which facilitates the identification by officers of medical benefit services of various providers, which require further investigation to determine whether they were or were not excessive services. The same investigations can also bring to light fraudulent claims by patients or providers of medical services. These arrangements apply to any providers of services, whether they be solo medical practitioners or health services vertically or horizontally integrated. The Government's concern is for the best use of the resources available consistent with the welfare of the patients.

(8) and (9) When foreign persons seek to operate Australian-owned private hospitals it would appear necessary for them to lease, hire or obtain a grant of rights to use assets of an Australian business. Such arrangements are covered by the provisions of section 21 of the Foreign Takeovers Act 1975 (the Act).
Sub-section 21 (2) of the Act provides that-
(2) Where the Treasurer is satisfied that-

(a) A person proposes to enter into an arrangement in relation to an Australian business carried on solely by a prescribed corporation or prescribed corporations or proposes to terminate an arrangement that exists in relation to such an Australian business. (Note that section 4 of the Act extends the operations of the Act to takeovers of businesses not carried on by prescribed corporations);
(b) the proposal, if carried out, would have the result that-
(i) in the case of a business not controlled by foreign persons-the business would be controlled by foreign persons; and

(ii) in the case of a business controlled by foreign persons-the business would continue to be controlled by foreign persons, but those persons would include a person who is not, or would not include a person who is, one of the foreign persons first referred to in this sub-paragraph; and

(c) that result would be contrary to the national interest, the Treasurer may make an order prohibiting the entering into of the proposed arrangement or prohibiting the termination of the existing arrangements as the case may be.

I am advised by the Department of the Treasury that they are unaware of circumstances whereby private hospitals could become foreign controlled through the circumvention of section 21 of the Foreign Takeovers Act. The Treasury Department has also been advised by the three U.S. companies operating private hospitals that they are not operating hospitals not owned by them.
(10) Yes. All takeovers of Australian business, irrespective of size, fall within the scope of the Foreign Takeovers Act.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Trachoma and Eye Health Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Aboriginal (a) adults, and (b) children underwent treatment during the original National Trachoma and Eye Health (NTEH) Program's Australia-wide survey.
(2) What was the success rate of treatment under this program in reducing the incidence and severity of trachoma and other eye disease.
(3) How many Aboriginal (a) adults, and (b) children have undergone treatment for trachoma and other eye diseases since the completion of the NTEH Program's Australia-wide survey.
(4) What has been the success rate of these treatments in reducing the incidence and severity of trachoma and other eye disease.
(5) What trachoma and eye health programs exist for Aboriginal (a) adults, and (b) children in each State.
(6) Does the Government intend to implement a national program for dealing with trachoma as suggested by the Royal College of Ophthalmologists in the NTEH Program's Report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) The report of the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program (NTEHP) which was tabled in the Parliament on 1 April 1980 provides details on these points.

(2) The success rate of the mass treatment programs conducted by the NTEHP in reducing the prevalence and severity of trachoma was assessed by the rescreening of groups at risk. This matter is also explained in some detail at page 157 et seq of the aforementioned report.

(3) (a) and (b) The total number of adults and children who have undergone treatment for trachoma and other eye disease since the completion of the NTEHP's Australia-wide survey is not known. In general, such activities constitute a part of general health care provided by State and Northern Territory health authorities and for which separate statistics are not available.

(4) There are difficulties in assessing the success of the treatment programs because of the many factors operating. In hyperendemic areas, and in environments characterised by inadequate clean water supplies, housing and sanitation, it is obvious that treatment programs can only provide temporary relief, because such conditions imply the existence of a continuing pool of infection. In addition, the prevalence of trachoma is affected by such factors as treatment coverage of the community, which in turn is affected by the degree of compliance and the degree of mobility within, and between communities (e.g. untreated newcomers to a community can be a source of reinfection). Thus, it should be borne in mind that any satisfactory interpretation of prevalence statistics is dependent on isolating and analysing these many associated variables. The health authorities in the Northern Territory, South Australia and Western Australia have provided the following details:

Northern Territory-As explained in answer to Senate Question 294, Hansard, 26 March 1981, page 868, the Northern Territory Department of Health has a special program which concentrates on children in Aboriginal communities. In situations where the disease is hyperendemic prevalence cannot be monitored by a system of individual case notifications. However, recent surveys have indicated a definite decrease in the severity of infections, and the Northern Territory Government has been actively promoting a five-year plan to upgrade water supplies and other basic services in Aboriginal communities.

South Australia-The South Australian Health Commission has advised that as a result of its programs adults have shown a general improvement in vision, often with the aid of spectacles, and children have shown a considerable decrease in incidence of trachoma from 26 per cent (in the NTEHP survey) to an estimated 7-12 per cent in 1981.

Western Australia-Community and Child Health Services has advised that in 1980 when its team saw 1776 children in the Kimberleys alone, the prevalence of trachoma there had decreased to 32 per cent. (The NTEHP in its survey of that area found a prevalence of 52 per cent, which was a decrease of about 40 per cent from the prevalence found by Professor Mann in her survey some 20 years previously.) Likewise, in the Murchison region there has been a decline in prevalence to 50 per cent in 1980-81. (The NTEHP found 64 per cent for this area, which was a decrease of 20-32 per cent from the prevalence found by Dr Eksteins in a survey some 20 years earlier.) It is uncertain whether this gradual decline in the prevalence of trachoma should be mainly attributed to treatment programs or environmental improvements, but it is probably due to a combination of both.
(5) (a) and (b) In most States trachoma and eye health programs are integrated into general health care programs.

In Queensland, for example, there are routine screening programs for visual acuity in primary school and pre-school children. Also, children under fifteen years in areas served by the Aboriginal Health Program are periodically screened by a variety of conditions by public health nurses. Apart from examination for discharging eyes, more specialised eye examinations are not performed, but public hospital facilities are available for diagnosis and treatment of trachoma and eye disease of adults and children.

In South Australia there is a co-ordinated program (comprising the South Australian Branch of the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists and the Aboriginal Health Unit of the Health Commission) for both Aboriginal adults and children. This provides thrice yearly visits by ophthalmologists to remote communities to assess and treat eye conditions. Visiting generalist doctors from the Central Australian Aboriginal Congress Medical Service, Alice Springs, from Ceduna and from Adelaide also monitor eye conditions. In addition to the above, children recevie a thrice yearly ntibiotic treatment regime, under specialist supervision, administered by Aboriginal Health Unit staff resident in remote communities.
The Northern Territory Department of Health operates a trachoma control program which was explained in some detail in response to Senate Question No. 294, Hansard, 26 March 1980, page 868.

In Western Australia in 1981 the Western Australian Eye Health Programme Co-ordinating Committee was formed. The Committee consists of representatives of the WA Branch of the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists and the WA Public Health Department. It has been extended to include Aboriginal representation from the Perth Aboriginal Medical Service, the Aboriginal Advisory Council and the National Aboriginal Conference. The Committee has met to formulate the policy and plans for the program in Western Australia and has been financed by the Community and Child Health Services Branch of the Public Health Department. The surveillance and treatment program for trachoma is conducted in each region by a team consisting of medical officers, a field nurse and Aboriginal health workers. Records are kept at district and regional offices. Visiting ophthalmologists and opticians are specialist members of the team. The Eye Health Program provides treatment and management for other eye diseases. In addition, the Lions Club also conducts glaucoma and amblyopia screening clinics at large regional centres, and these are free, and open to the general public.

In relation to the control of trachoma (and other infections) all health authorities emphasise the need to upgrade the poor environmental conditions, expecially inadequate water supplies, which exist in many Aboriginal communities. To assist in overcoming these environmental deficiencies, the Commonwealth Government has agreed to commit $50m over a five-year period to an Aboriginal Public Health Improvement Program. $8m of this has been allocated for 1981-82.

(6) In recognition of the need for additional eye-health services, a proposal is currently being developed by the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists. This is being based on the specific requirements for ongoing care in each area. Subject to consultation and agreement with State health authorities and Aboriginal representatives, a program will be implemented with Commonwealth financial assistance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 19 August, 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister take urgent action to protect the jobs of meatworkers and other country people who depend on meatworks for their livelihood by introducing a quota on livestock exports in the form of a ratio of live animal to processed meat exports, as the present tendency toward live meat exports from Australia is causing abattoirs to face one of the poorest seasons on record.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is acutely aware of the current difficulties being faced by the meat processing industry and of the impact this is having on country people where rural meatworks are involved. However to attribute responsibility for the problems faced by abattoirs to livestock exports is to misunderstand the causes of the current problems and the nature of the livestock trade.

The present circumstances facing the processing sector must be seen against the general decline in cattle numbers over the last five years and the consequent fall in abattoir throughput. The causes of this decline are complex, but include the recent drought and competing prospects for alternative enterprises such as grains and wool.
However there is no doubt that a major factor in producer decisions to reduce herd size was the restrictive action taken against imports in our major markets in the mid 70's.

The Government has undertaken a major effort, on behalf of the meat industry, to negotiate improved market access for beef, especially in MTN agreements with the United States of America, Japan, Canada and the EEC. These agreements provide a more stable and secure framework for the future development of the Australian industry.

It would be a mistake to assume that in the current situation, processed meat could simply be substituted for livestock exports. Consumers in the Middle East, for example, have a strong preference for fresh killed meat. If the Government were to interfere in this trade in the manner suggested the most likely result would be a fall-off in the live trade without any consequent increase in the volume of carcase meat from Australia taken by that region.

On the other hand, the closer trading links forged with the Middle East through the development of the livestock trade has probably been a major factor in the expansion of our meat trade to the region. In the decade to 30 June 1980, sheepmeat exports have increased from 11,415 tonnes to 71,907 tonnes and exports of beef have also grown from 1,213 tonnes to 34,760 tonnes over this period.

This is not to say that the Government is not sympathetic with the present difficulties in the meat processing industry. While the need for rationalisation has to be faced squarely, the Government is prepared to examine carefully any constructive proposal to assist meat processors.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Rank-General Electric Company in Melbourne in June this year attempt to sack seven women process workers who were receiving workers' compensation after contracting tenosynovitis on the job.

(2) Did this result in a strike by members of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, Electrical Trades Union and Storemen and Packers Union at the Melbourne factory between 26 June and 2 July 1981.
(3) Are all seven workers still employed by Rank-General Electric and is their future employment under review.
(4) What protection do such workers have against unjust dismissal because they have been injured at work.
(5) Has the Industrial Relations Bureau investigated this incident; if so, what action has resulted.
(6) If no action has been taken, will the Minister ensure that this incident is investigated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Rank-General Electric Housewares Pty Ltd of Notting Hill, Victoria has advised my Department that in May 1981 the company had raised with the AMWSU the situation involving seven process workers who had been on long term workers' compensation because of tenosynovitis, but that at no time had there been any suggestion of the company issuing dismissal notices to these employees.

(2) Rank-General Electric Housewares has informed the Department that due to a misunderstanding between the parties over the employment of the seven employees, a mass meeting of about 500 employees (AMWSU members and others) occurred on 24 or 25-6-81. That meeting decided to commence a stoppage on 26-6-81 in the belief that the seven process workers could face dismissal. Normal work was resumed by some employees on 2.7.81 with the remaining employees returning the following day. This resumption was achieved on the basis of an agreement under which the company agreed to:
introduce a health rehabilitation program on an ongoing basis;
introduce immediately a health program (training and awareness) to be coordinated by an ergonomist;
union representatives conducting a survey of employees in connection with job design and job rotation which is to be examined and discussed with management.

(3) Rank-General Electric Housewares has advised that there have been no dismissals of employees because of tenosynovitis and that the future of the seven employees in question will be reviewed following their completion of the new rehabilitation program.

(4) Broadly speaking, legislation concerning unfair dismissal is a matter for the States. For constitutional reasons, the Commonwealth's legislative powers in this area are basically confined to its own employees.

At common law, there is no special protection of the employment of injured workers. Such persons are in the same position and have the same remedy as workers who claim to have been unfairly dismissed, which is to sue for damages; although NSW and SA have provided additional remedies legislatively.

The position of injured workers has also been dealt with in awards and agreements reached in many industries between employers and unions that provide for the payment of accident pay to employers on workers compensation. The accident pay is designed to make up the difference between the level of workers compensation and the award rate that would have been received if the worker had not been injured.

A worker's entitlement to accident pay under an award or agreement exists generally as long as he/she is entitled to workers compensation even though his or her employment may have been terminated. Provision is made in both awards and agreements that prevent the employer terminating the employment of an injured worker to avoid the payment of accident pay. Breaches of federal award provisions are actionable under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904. Breaches of private agreements may be sued for at common law.

(5) The Director of the Industrial Relations Bureau has advised me that the Bureau does not have details of and has not investigated the incident. I understand that the Bureau's policy is to conduct inspections of all respondents to federal awards as frequently as possible to ensure that those respondents are complying with their award obligations. In addition, the Bureau does investigate specific complaints of alleged breaches of the Act, regulations and of awards.

(6) The Director has indicated to me that upon receipt of more specific information the Bureau would examine the matter to determine whether there may have been a breach of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act or regulations or of a federal award.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

(2) There is no suggestion that the particular recommendation was directed specifically towards Mount Isa. The basis for the recommendation is set out in paragraph 5.8 of the report, that is:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Joint Iron and Steel Industry: Departmental Dumping Evaluation Committee

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why was it considered necessary to set up a Joint Iron and Steel Industry/Departmental Dumping Evaluation Committee when companies could already lodge dumping complaints direct with the Department.
(2) Why are only steel producers, and not consumers, represented on the Committee.

(3) Will the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs give an undertaking that all secondary rolling mills will be guaranteed supplies of steel from Australian producers at real market prices before prohibiting imports.
Will the Minister guarantee that all independent secondary rolling mills can purchase steel at the same prices as producer-owned mills.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Iron and Steel Dumping Evaluation Committee was established to facilitate the submission of evidence of alleged dumping in relation to mill products of the iron and steel industry.

In taking this action the Minister said he was conscious of the considerable levels of excess capacity in the iron and steel industry throughout the world, and that many developed countries had acted to control imports and influence prices. These actions by other countries carried with them the risk of diverting exports of iron and steel products at dumped prices to Australia, with a consequent threat of injury to the Australian iron and steel industry.

(2) The Committee acts as the complainant and submits evidence to the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs for possible initiation of anti-dumping action. It is for the Department, as distinct from the Committee, to independently evaluate the evidence, to determine whether a prima facie case has been made, and to carry out overseas inquiries if appropriate.
Consistent with the complainant role of the Committee it is not appropriate for sectors of the industry other than manufacturers to be represented on the Committee.
There is provision for the interests of importers and others to be represented during the process of the Department's evaluation.
(3) Imports of steel would not be prohibited under the anti-dumping legislation and if priced at normal values they would not attract dumping duties.

(4) It is not appropriate for the Minister to make guarantees relating to the commercial practice of firms in the industry, other than to say that normal provisions under the Trade Practices and Dumping legislation will apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 August 1981, (Hansard, page 50), Senator Sibraa asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice concerning Australia Post's acceptance of new mail contractors.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Australia Post is required, under the terms of the Postal Services Act 1975, to pursue, where practicable, a financial policy to enable it to meet all operating costs from revenue and to contribute at least half the amount required for capital expenditure.

Against this background, Australia Post continually reviews its services, including rural mail deliveries, to ensure that they are carried out as economically and efficiently as practicable, and that resources are used to the best advantage.

Before a contract for a mail delivery service is advertised, Australia Post assesses the order of costs which could be involved in performance of the particular service. This assessment is taken into account in considering the suitability of tenders received.
Prescribed procedures of particular importance in selecting a suitable tender at a satisfactory price, under the competitive public tendering system, follow:

Every consideration is given to a re-tender from an existing contractor who has held a contract for some years and has given satisfactory service over that period. In these circumstances, Australia Post may apply a loading (up to a prescribed maximum), to the tender prices quoted by other tenderers, to take account of the expertise and demonstrated satisfactory service of the longstanding contractor.

If the lowest tender received is so low that it would appear to preclude the satisfactory operation of the service, the tenderer is interviewed and given the opportunity to withdraw or to revise the tender. (Australia Post's assessment of an acceptable price depends to some extent on whether a contractor proposes to carry mail exclusively or in conjunction with other freight. In the latter circumstance, a lower price would be expected.)

If a new tender is lodged, all other tenderers are invited to re-tender also. If the tenderer confirms the price, however, and it is clear to Australia Post that it would not be possible to provide a satisfactory service at that price, then the next lowest tender may be considered. If the price submitted by that tenderer were considered too low also, the process described above would continue until an acceptable level is reached.

In addition to price considerations tenderers are assessed in terms of suitability to conduct the advertised service in a competent manner. Particular efforts are made also to ensure that the tenderer is fully informed of all of Australia Post's requirements before a contract is let. If the lowest tenderer is not considered suitable, the process described above continues until a suitable tenderer can be found.

Within Australia Post, mail contracting matters are dealt with by field management. If Senator Sibraa knows of any case which he believes should be investigated, Australia Post would be pleased to have the matter reviewed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 August 1981 (Hansard, pages 249-250), Senator Harradine asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice concerning person to person telephone calls.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In response to House of Representatives Question No. 1157 (Hansard, 3 June 1981, page 3068) I stated that the Left Word procedure has a number of service shortcomings. These included Telecom's inability to ensure the message reached the wanted party. A common situation was that on receiving word that he/she was required, the person concerned would originate an STD call to the calling party nullifying the original call. Studies showed that more than fifty per cent of all calls using the Left Word procedure were outstanding at the end of a day.

These problems have been overcome by the Try Again procedure, where the operator ascertains when the particular person is likely to be available, and makes follow-up attempts to bring the call to a successful conclusion.

It is Telecom's policy to notify its customers of operating changes only in cases where an existing service is withdrawn, or where all subscribers are affected by a major change to existing procedures.

In this change of practice the Left Word procedure has been replaced by what is considered a much better service to subscribers both in terms of ensuring that the called party is made aware he/she is wanted, and that the call is connected at the earliest possible opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 August 1981 (Hansard, page 319), Senator Sibraa asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Since we are nearing the end of the International Year of Disabled Persons I wonder whether the Minister is aware of how popular the new pushbutton telephone is to those disabled people, such as the blind, who have always experienced difficulty with the normal dial telephone. Is the Minister also aware that the additional rental and changeover charges for the pushbutton telephone are in excess of $70, which is prohibitive for most pensioners who are anxious to acquire one? The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

This is in line with the recommendations of the Vernon Commission of Inquiry into the former Australian Post Office and the approach that has been adopted in the case of the telephone rental concession for eligible pensioners, which is funded by direct appropriations to the Departments of Social Security and Veterans' Affairs which in return reimburse Telecom.

Similarly, since 1978 special concessional rates have applied for Touchfones provided in cases approved by the Department of Social Security where the facility is required by a disabled person undergoing a rehabilitation program sponsored by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service. In such cases the Department of Social Security meets the $20 once only charge and $28 installation fee (the latter applicable only where a change of instrument is involved), and Telecom waives the additional $24 annual rental.

As you are aware Telecom already provides some concessions for the disabled, for example, a one-third discount on rental and installation fees for certain facilities designed for the benefit of the disabled. However, Telecom is not presently in a position to offer further concessions such as Touchfones to disabled persons on the basis suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 August 1981 (Hansard, page 384) Senator Bolkus asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the decision in last week's Budget to amend the sales tax Acts and to place glace fruits in the schedule of items attracting a 17 1/2 per cent tax to correct a so-called anomaly or inconsistency. Is it true that in general foodstuffs are exempt from sales tax and that on page 19 of the Budget Speech the Treasurer specifically excluded food from the new imposition? Does the Government decision therefore create and not correct an inconsistency? Is it true that this decision was taken without industry consultation or advice? Is it also true that appeal provisions under the sales tax legislation will not operate before 1 January 1982 although the increased taxes operate immediately, ensuring that effective relief may not be available to this industry and others until it is too late? Since the industry is vital to South Australia's Barossa Valley and Murray River areas, and since such a hefty tax increase will have disastrous effects on sales and the demand for both fruit and labour in an industry which is worth $3.5m to the South Australian economy, will the Government undertake to reconsider these two ill-considered decisions?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
With the exception of confectionery and beverages, foodstuffs for human consumption have been exempt from sales tax for many years.
In the Budget Speech it was indicated that the existing exemption for foodstuffs would not be affected by the 2.5 per cent tax proposed for a range of goods that are currently exempt.

The decision to include glace fruits among the goods classifiable as confectionery places them on an equal footing with crystallized fruit which is also specifically classified as confectionery. This removes an inconsistency which previously existed.
The Government did not consider it necessary to consult the industry about the elimination of an unintended inconsistency in the law.

The appeal procedures referred to involve a proposal to give taxpayers a right of objection and appeal to the classification of goods under the sales tax law where that classification is in doubt. That proposal was released for public comment on 20 August 1981 but is not, at this stage, the subject of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September 1981 (Hansard, page 720) Senator Robert Ray asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I preface my question to the Minister for Finance by saying that in the recent sales tax increases the Kit Kat biscuit produced by Rowntree Hoadley Ltd was redefined as confectionery. This product has previously been exempt as a wafer biscuit but is now subject to a 17 1/2 per cent sales tax. Is the Minister aware of the burden imposed on Rowntree Hoadley by broadening the sales tax? Is the Government concerned at the probable sacking of 50 to 75 employees by that firm? Can the Minister guarantee that there will be a re-examination of the interpretation of the Kit Kat as this product is defined as a biscuit in every other country in which it is produced? Finally, as the Australian Customs Tariff defines Kit Kat as a biscuit, does the Government intend to deal with this anomaly?
The Treasury has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

On 15 September 1981 Senator Ray asked a number of questions about sales tax payable on Kit Kat biscuits. One question was related to the treatment of Kit Kat biscuits as confectionery for the purposes of the sales tax law when for Customs Tariff purposes they are regarded as biscuits. I said at the time that I would ask the Treasurer to look into this matter.

I am advised by the Treasurer that the different classifications of Kit Kat under the sales tax and Customs Tariff laws are not inconsistent. Customs Tariff serves a completely different purpose to sales tax. The particular Customs Tariff item refers to biscuits including chocolate coated ones.

The sales tax classification of 'Kit Kat' does not turn on any identity it has as a biscuit. There is no specific exemption from sales tax for biscuits. Biscuits may qualify for exemption under a general provision, item 35C in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, which exempts foodstuffs for human consumption. Confectionery is excluded from the exemption under item 35C and, as a result of the recent amendments to the sales tax law, confectionery is defined to include goods marketed as confectionery or consisting principally of confectionery. Thus any foodstuff, including biscuits, which is marketed as confectionery or consists principally of confectionery does not qualify for exemption under item 35C.

Kit Kats are marketed as confectionery in competition with other confectionery lines. It was regarded as anomalous that Kit Kats were exempt when competitive confectionery lines were taxable. The anomally has been removed by making Kit Kats taxable along with other comparable lines which are marketed as confectionery.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 September (Hansard, pages 751-752) Senator Missen asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question, without notice, concerning a report on the capacity for sharing resources in technical and further education external studies between the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 September 1981 (Hansard, pages 821-822) Senator Coleman asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the health hazards of lead intake.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

I am aware of the report of the Australian Academy of Science. The Academy of Science report was similar to that of the Department of Health and Social Security (DHSS) Working Party in the United Kingdom which published its report 'Lead and Health' in 1980, in attributing less than a quarter of the lead absorbed by adults and less than one-tenth of the lead in children directly to airborne lead.

The Academy also attributed an unspecified proportion of lead intake in children to lead in dust, a large proportion of which in urban areas comes from airborne lead settling out. Although the Academy is not specific about how much lead comes from dust, it can be calculated from the figures in the report that under certain circumstances this may even be close to the amount absorbed from both food and air.

The National Health & Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) recommended limits for lead in foods in 1960 and, after discussions with the food industry, has since reduced the amount permitted. The most recent reduction of lead permitted in food was approved by the NH & MRC in October 1980.
This reduction means that the maximum permitted concentration of lead in infant foods is as follows:
(1) the lead content of infant foods in containers other than tin plate must not exceed 0.3 mg/kg;
(2) for those infant foods packaged in tin plate containers the mean level of lead in ten samples must not exceed 0.3 mg/kg and the lead content of any single sample must not exceed 0.8 mg/kg.

These recommendations have been referred to the Australian States and Territories for adoption into legislation and the levels, which are comparable with those of other Western countries, have already been adopted in Tasmania and are in the process of adoption in other States.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 September 1981 (Hansard, page 825) Senator Townley asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of today which states:
The editor of a partly Government-owned newspaper in Zimbabwe which disclosed that North Korean military instructors were in the country has been sacked.
The editor . . . reported in the Umtali Post that a large contingent of north Koreans was near Umtali and accompanied the story with a critical editorial.

Will the Minister ascertain and inform the Senate whether that editor was sacked because the article was accurate or because it was inaccurate, and what would be the Australian Government's attitude if it were agreed that North Korean military instructors are in Zimbabwe?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
In relation to this matter the Zimbabwean Minister of Information Dr Nathan Shamuyaria made the following statement in the Parliament of Zimbabwe on 17 September:

'The former Editor of the Umtali Post, Mrs Maitland-Stuart, was appointed to that post and that paper before it was purchased by the Zimbabwe Mass Media Trust. After the purchase last January, she and other Editors were told that they would be replaced as and when new Editors were identified. She was due to retire at the end of this year.

However, on Friday 7th August, as the honourable member Mr Butler has said, she published the following editorial, which I would like to quote for the information of honourable members. It was titled: 'Sinister Trend'.

Foreign troops are now based in Manicaland. The arrival in Inyanga this week of North Korean soldiers, understood to be the first of a large contingent, is a sinister development. What have they come for? How long will they be here? We would have thought that Zimbabwe had a big enough army of its own for the defence of this country, without requiring help from anyone, least of all foreigners from Eastern Asia. There are now Cubans in Angola and Ethiopia, Koreans in Zimbabwe, East Germans in Mozambique, Chinese in Tanzania and Zambia, to name a few. Is this the freedom Africa seeks? We see it as neocolonialism of the worst kind. The Minister of Defence must tell us all why the Koreans are here.
That was the Editorial-

Now firstly, the Editorial was inaccurate in several essential respects. We called her to Salisbury to ascertain the sources of her information. She was not called in to be dismissed, but to be questioned on the inaccurate facts in the Editorial. For example, there was no large contingent of Koreans coming to Inyanga. The Minister of Defence had announced that 106 instructors had arrived to train the 5th Brigade. There was no intention to use the Korean personnel across our borders in Mozambique. The statement that was published on the front page of the same paper which prevoked the editorial which stated that Koreans were to be used across the border. Why has she not questioned the presence of British officers who are training the national army, and as Comrade Mudzingwa has said, why did she not question the presence of South African troops in the country. We felt she had used words in the sense of a military occupation.

I indicated to her at that meeting that the editorial had adopted a South African line in opposing the presence of any personnel from Eastern Communist countries. There are no Chinese in Zambia or Tanzania or East Germans in Mozambique in the sense of military occupation. There are, of course, Embassy staff and experts in various scientific fields, in each case, especially in the case of Zambia and Tanzania British pesonnel are far in the majority in those countries. She has not questioned that.

But it is the South African thinking behind this editorial of opposing the presence of any personnel from any countries other than Western Europe. As a non-aligned nation, this view is diametrically opposed to our own view. We welcome and interact with all nationalities, especially those who supported us in the patriotic war of national liberation.

Thirdly, the editorial was racist, again betraying a basic South Africa attitude. Examine the phrase which was in the editorial I have just read saying, 'least of all foreigners from Eastern Asia', implying foreigners from Western Europe or America would be tolerable. This editor had not opposed, as I said earlier, the activities of the South African army in Angola nd Mozambique. This racist thinking is totally unacceptable to the Government of independent Zimbabwe.

The Prime Minister and I made our views known about Mrs Maitland-Stuart to the management of Zimbabwe newspapers and to the Mass Media Trust, which owns the majority shareholding. Taking our views into acount, the management decided to terminate the services of Mrs Maitland-Stuart. I should stress it was not the Government which dismissed her-we merely made our views known loudly and clearly. The Chairman of the Mass Media Trust, Dr Sadza, was as appalled as we were by the views of the Editor. He informed us that he would be consulting with his fellow Trustees with a view to taking action they thought appropriate. In turn they instructed their representatives on the Board of Zimbabwe Newspapers to take the action they thought appropriate.

The Government and the Mass Media Trust are at one that fifth columnists and racists must be weeded out of our newspapers and Mass Media Institutions. Only those honourable members designing to undermine the state can condone such actions and activities.

Of course, we cannot be told about the freedom of the press. We are in the process of establishing, since we came into power, a free press in the country. There has never been a free press because journalists were detained and some died in prison. One of our most outstanding journalists, Comrade Edison Sithole, an eminent writer, disappeared at the hands of the members opposite. I am only recounting facts of which we are all aware and which are well documented. When we took over the Ministry of Information there was the well-known practice of censorship. At one time the members opposite had 14 information officers working as censors on newspapers. So that newspapers could not print anything which they wanted without passing the eyes of the censors. We have no censors and that is why people like Mrs Maitland-Stuart can print the kind of things she did. As I said in my statement that is why we made our views known and I am glad the Mass Media Trust acted accordingly.'
The above statement is self-explanatory and not one to which the Australian Government has anything to add.

In relation to the other matter you raised concerning the presence of North Korean instructors in Zimbabwe, the Australian Government's attitude is that the decision of the Government of Zimbabwe to accept the North Korean offer of military training is entirely a matter for that Government and is consistent with its policy of non-alignment. Mr Mugabe has said that other units of the defence forces of Zimbabwe will continue to be trained with the assistance of the British Military Training Team, in accordance with the agreement between the Governments of Zimbabwe and the United Kingdom.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September 1981 (Hansard, page 850), Senator Haines asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question without notice concerning the Commonwealth Research Centres of Excellence scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September, 1981 (Hansard, page 895) Senator Watson asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the reason why the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) has not granted an export licence to Phil-Bai International Pty Ltd and whether this will mean that the company will source its meat from New Zealand for export to the Philippines.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In December 1979 the Philippines Government established Phil-Bai, a state trading organisation, to undertake the import of meat and livestock from Australia and New Zealand. Phil-Bai is controlled by the Philippines Bureau of Animal Industry. Following this decision, a company, Phil-Bai International Pty Ltd, was established in Australia with 90 per cent Philippine Government and 10 per cent Australian interests.

In July, 1980, Phil-Bai International applied to the AMLC for export licences for meat and livestock. The application was refused on the grounds that the Corporation was opposed to granting an Australian export licence to the purchasing arm of a foreign Government sole import agency. This general policy of the AMLC is designed to protect the interests of the Australian industry in dealing with foreign sole importing agencies by preserving for the Corporation the right to step into the market itself as a sole seller so that it can, if necessary, deal with a sole buyer on equal terms.

As Phil-Bai has been able to arrange purchases of meat in Australia and arrange with licensed exporters to export the meat to the Philippines, the policy decision by the AMLC has not materially affected Phil-Bai's commercial interests. A number of Australian meat exporters have expressed satisfaction with the trading links they have established with Phil-Bai. There does not appear to have been any significant diversion of trade away from Australia to New Zealand because of the AMLC's action. Total exports of meat to the Philippines from Australia in 1980-81 were around 4,800 tonnes, compared to 5,300 tonnes for 1979-80.
I wish to state clearly that the Philippines is a valued trading partner of Australia and the Australian Government will do whatever it can to facilitate trade with the Philippines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September, (Hansard, page 896) Senator Watson asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, a question without notice regarding Government measures to encourage research into, and the manufacture of, integrated circuits and other high technology products in Australia. Senator Watson also asked what the Government is doing to ensure that, in the future, Australia does not have to import this type of technology and related devices at a large premium.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Science and Technology advises as follows:

High technology products are assuming increasing importance in industry, commerce, government and the community. The Government recognises this and believes that the wider use of these and other technological innovations is crucial to Australia's continued industrial development.

A major influence on this process, as well as that of industrial research and development, is the existence of a favourable economic climate. The Government's policies, which are designed to maintain a climate of economic growth and improved opportunities for business, are therefore a pre-requisite for the creation and growth of firms in these industries.

The honourable senator will be aware that Australia already has a developed microelectronics industrial capacity including the production of computer equipment and the development of systems and applications software.

The Australian computer industry will benefit from the Government's recent decision to give preference to Australian products in government purchases of microelectronic equipment and other high technology goods. Moreover, the broader question of assistance to the computer industry will be referred to the IAC by early 1982 to provide time for a review of assistance measures prior to the expiration of the ADP Bounty Act in 1984.

At the technical level, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has established a research group to develop integrated circuits which exploit more fully the potential for miniaturisation of electronic components. If successful, the results will greatly assist Australian industry in gaining a share of the burgeoning range of applications for microelectronic technologies.
The Government also expects to receive in the near future, a report from the Australian Science and Technology Council on the microelectronics industry in Australia.

The honourable senator will recall that the Government has appropriated nearly $50m for industrial research and development incentives in 1981-82. In this regard, computer manufacturing companies are eligible to receive grants under the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act. Of the $23m provided under the Act in 1979-80 for project grants, nearly $1m was allocated directly for Industrial R&D in the fields of computing and microelectronics. Under recent amendments to the IR&D Incentives Act, computer software research and development is also eligible for project grant assistance. However, such activities must relate directly to the development of new products or new or improved processes employed in manufacturing, mining or certain on-site construction operations. In addition, further $1.9m was spent in the fields of computing and microelectronics under the public interest provision of the IR&D Incentives Act and through Industry Productivity Improvement Programs administered by the Department of Science and Technology.

The Government has also assisted in promoting community awareness of the benefits and opportunites offered by high technology products. An example of this is Information Technology Week which was sponsored by the Department of Science and Technology in conjunction with the Australian Computer Society during August this year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 September 1981 (Hansard, page 981), Senator Primmer asked me the following question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Has the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry noticed media reports of the discovery of further meat switching at a Melbourne meat works?

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1163) Senator Robertson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question without notice:

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1360) Senator Bonner asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that it was reported in the Queensland Press that the Australian Workers Union is about to rejoin the new guard of the Labor Party? The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that, because of the secrecy provisions of the income tax law, he is unable to provide information concerning the payment of tax by particular organisations. By way of general comment, however, the Commissioner advised that the income of all bodies or associations corporate or unincorporate is liable to tax but section 23 (f) of the Income Tax Assessment Act specifically exempts the income of a trade union and the income of an association of employees or employers registered under any Commonwealth or State Act, or under any law in force in a Territory being part of Australia relating to the settlement of industrial disputes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1722) Senator Coates asked me a question without notice about Commonwealth assistance to the people of Zeehan for damage caused by the bushfires in early February this year. In my response to Senator Coates, I undertook to make inquiries as to whether there had been some delay in the payment of Commonwealth assistance and to see through my Department that no unnecessary delays occur.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

Under the natural disaster relief arrangements, it is necessary for the States to submit formal claims to the Commonwealth before payment of Commonwealth assistance can be made. I am advised by my Department that to the date of preparing this reply no such claim has been received from the Tasmanian Government in respect of expenditures incurred on approved measures of assistance for Zeehan bushfire relief and restoration. Once a claim is submitted, I can assure the honourable Senator that it will be processed promptly and the appropriate payments made without delay.
